title: Brexit news Jeremy Corbyn Caroline Flint Chequers no deal
story: Caroline Flint has claimed she will throw her weight behind&nbspTheresa May's Brexit deal, and urged her Labour colleagues to reflect on why you would not support a Brexit deal.&nbspMs Flint, who voted Remain but has since accepted the result, also took issue with how politicians and supporters of the People's Vote campaign had treated Brexit voters.Speaking to Sophy Ridge on Sky News, the Labour Brexiteer claimed that hardline Remainers had been both patronising and offensive to those who want to leave the EU.The latest remarks from the Labour MP come as a growing&nbspnumber of backbenchers &nbspbreak ranks with Corbyn to back a deal with the EU.                Brussels stunned as MAJORITY of EU citizens question its powerLast week, the Prime Minister&nbspmade a bold appeal&nbspdirectly to Labour voters&nbspcalling on them to back her decent, moderate and patriotic Tory party.&nbspAt September's Labour conference,&nbspShadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said: &ldquoIf Theresa May brings back a deal that fails our tests &ndash and that looks increasingly likely - Labour will vote against it. No ifs, no buts.This appeared to confirm that Labour will whip its MPs to vote against any deal that Mrs May brings back to the Commons.&nbspHowever, Ms Flint put her support behind a reasonable deal if the other options on thetable were a second referendum or a no deal scenario.&nbspShe said: The question for my Labour colleagues is why wouldn&rsquot you support a deal?Flint criticised how politicians and supporters of the People's Vote had treated Brexit voters (Image:  SKY)Why would you stand alongside Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg who want us to crash out?That doesn&rsquot serve country&rsquos interests or Labour&rsquos interests.She also attacked how Remainers had continued to belittle Brexit voters.Ms Flint told Ridge: These politicians don&rsquot understand them and their choice of words is both patronising and offensive.Even on social media, whenever I have stood up for the people I represent andl let&rsquos remember every region of England outside of London voted Leave, you immediately get trolled and shut down.The language used by politicians and those involved in the People&rsquos Vote campaign and those that want to overturn the referendum is patronising.They say the Brexit voters were ill-informed, uneducated, that they didn&rsquot know what they were voting for.But people did have an understanding. They knew it would be seismic in terms of their county.We are stuck between hardline Brexiteers who don&rsquot want a deal and hardline Remainers who want to overturn the referendum result.If it is a reasonable deal, I would vote for itLabour MP Ruth Smeeth, for Stoke North, has recently said: &ldquoIf the option is voting for the deal or voting for something that would mean no deal &ndash well, I&rsquom not prepared to vote for no-deal.Brexit-backing Labour MPs such as Kate Hoey and Frank Field could also rebel against their party's leadership to back Mrs May.

title: Brexit news update Emily Thornberry Andrew Marr show Labour Brexit tests
story: The Shadow Foreign Secretary was put on the spot by BBC host Andrew Marr as he said Labour's Brexit tests have been designed to make May's final deal fail in Parliament.The BBC host pointed out one of the tests says Theresa May's Brexit deal must guarantee the UK will maintain the same benefits of being a member of the EU outside of the bloc.&nbspA provision which Mr Marr claimed to be impossible to achieve unless the Prime Minister agrees to keep the UK in the customs union and the single market.&nbspHe said: &ldquoYou mentioned your tests a couple of times but they&rsquore a bit silly, aren&rsquot they?                NO DEAL BREXIT EXPLAINED: What does a it mean for immigration?                PM needs to find her inner Trump to beat Brussels, says TIM NEWARKIf you say we must have the exact same benefits then that means that we have to stay inside the single market and the customs union.&ldquoOtherwise we can&rsquot possibly have the exact same benefits.&ldquoSo it does seem to a lot of people these are tests designed for the Government to fail them.&ldquoThey&rsquore intended to provoke a parliamentary crisis because you want a general election as soon as possible.Brexit news: Andrew Marr challenges Emily Thornberry on Labour's Brexit tests (Image: BBC)The Labour frontbencher responded arguing Theresa May had already agreed to meet Labour tests on the final agreement with Brussels.&nbspShe added Labour will be merely holding the Prime Minister to her promise.&nbspShe said: When Theresa May said she was going to get this deal and we said we will have six tests and she said &lsquooh, it&rsquos fine. I&rsquom going to be able to agree on all of that&rsquo.&ldquo&lsquoMy agreement will meet your test.&rsquo That&rsquos what the Prime Minister said.&ldquoAnd we&rsquore holding her to it.Ms Thornberry hit out at Theresa May's government for playing chicken over the Brexit deal.She added: They have been faffing around for two years.We shouldn't be having a deal where Theresa May comes to an agreement that says 'we haven't been able to agree anything in the last two years but we're going to agree something in the next two years.It's a false choice. We're not agreeing to building half a bridge when we don't know where it goes.

title: scottish plan to plant 500 acres of broadleaf trees above the A83
story: The Rest and Be Thankful Woodland Creation Project was approved in August (Image: NC)The motorists have been forced to take a 60-mile detour since Tuesday when 2,500 tonnes of debris tumbled down Ben Luibhean blocking the main road and the Old Military Road which is normally used as a relief route.However, after another 300 tonnes of debris on the A83 and another 50 tonnes on the old road came down on Friday, there is no quick solution for the ongoing access issue.Three huge boulders - including one weighing 75 tonnes - which were trapped in the steel catch fences on the mountain earlier on in the week have been secured by engineers but difficult conditions brought on by Storm Callum hampered further clearance efforts.Forestry Commission Scotland (FCS) and Transport Scotland are planning to plant 500 acres of native broadleaf trees and shrubs on the slopes above the A83 to reduce erosion and increase stability.                A483 traffic update: A483 CLOSED after lorry and tractor crash                 Traffic lights could soon be removed from UK roads, this is whyThe Rest and Be Thankful Woodland Creation Project was approved in August after a public consultation and the planting of up to 250,000 trees is scheduled to start in 2020.However, work cannot begin until the land is purchased from the current owner, who uses the barren slopes for rough sheep grazing.Even then, it will be at least 15 years before the new forest starts to reduce landslides in the steep-sided mountain pass between Tarbert and Arrochar.The project was first put forward in 2012 in a report for FCS by Bill Raynor and Bruce Nicoll of Forest Research in Edinburgh.They said it would not be possible to plant quick-growing conifers in such a windy location and suggested reintroducing a mix of native species that would have covered the slopes before they were cleared for sheep grazing.The species included ash, aspen, bird cherry, blackthorn, common alder, downy birch, eared willow, hawthorn, hazel, holly, rowan and sessile oak, with blaeberry and wood sorrel ground vegetation.In the same year, a report by Transport Scotland concluded that low-height broadleaf trees and shrubs should be planted alongside other measures such as deer fences and engineering work.As well as the land ownership issue, the impact on golden eagles, black grouse and badgers and concerns from hikers and mountaineers have also complicated matters since then.The SNP Government has focused instead on opening the relief route and has spent &pound10million on measures such as netting, drainage and road safety works.Despite this massive outlay, the road has been closed on dozens of occasions causing long delays for motorists and the emergency services and damaging the rural economy of Argyll.Jamie Greene, Scottish Conservative transport spokesman, said the landslips caused enormous disruption and inconvenience for everyone in the local area and added: While clearly a previous attempt has been made to prevent this kind of landslip, it has not worked.                M4 crash: Three dead after minibus and lorry collision                M26 traffic: Kent motorway CLOSED to prepare for Brexit no dealThe species included ash, aspen, bird cherry, blackthorn, common alder and many more (Image: AGF)&ldquoThere are questions to be asked about why an alternative approach that was suggested in 2012 has not been tried.&ldquoIf tree planting is the best solution, as suggested in this document, then we may have simply wasted 6 years.A Transport Scotland spokesman said: The plan to plant trees above the A83 Rest and Be Thankful to help mitigate landslips cannot begin until the complex land purchase process is complete and the necessary planning permission is in place. Transport Scotland has been working closely with the existing landowner and partner agencies and it is hoped these will be finalised in the near future, allowing preparatory works to begin in the new year.Work has already begun on a further &pound2m worth of additional mitigation measures, including the construction of road side catch pits.&ldquoThese measures, which were agreed with the A83 Taskforce, will help improve the resilience of the A83 and help keep Argyll open for business.

title: brexit theresa may conservative labour
story: We understand her desperation to avoid no-deal.It would be damaging for both sides, which is why German and Spanish businesses are panicking.But to challenge the DUP to like her deal or lump it, when they are openly threatening to defeat the Budget, looks reckless.Eventhey don’t, she still needs their votes to govern post-Brexit.And can the Prime Minister really trust the supposedly sensible wing of the Labour Party to make up the numbers on the final deal The worst of it, though, is agreeing to stay in the EU’s Customs Union “temporarily” but with no firm exit date.It is simply dishonest to spend two years talking up our golden opportunities to embrace global free trade and new industriesyou know that, in ­reality, we could be trapped forever in a deal that snuffs them out.We MUST be out of the Customs Union by the next election.Our future and the Government’s survival depend on it.NOTHING is more toxic to a party’s fortunes than betraying promises to voters.Brown did it. Clegg too. Theresa May doesn’t seem to have learned the lesson.Announcing that “austerity is over” looks hasty. Corbyn will throw it back at her whenever ANY spending is cut.The same goes for the PM’s manesto pledges to cut tax on “businesses and working families”.Chancellor Philip Hammond plainly intends the opposite to fund her NHS splurge.The Tories claim “we will always be a party of low tax”. How, with the overall burden already at a -year high FOR all the gloom, it could be worse. We could be victims of John McDonnell’s socialist fantasy, as the children dying of hunger in Venezuela are.Inflation there has hit ten million per cent. Yes, you read that right.The squalor and misery are almost unimaginable. Yet just four years ago the Shadow Chancellor rejoiced that the once-rich South American country was now experiencing “socialism in action”.The warning signs of collapse were already there. Essentials were running out. Renationalisations, price controls, the trampling on the rule of law and lack of private investment saw to that.McDonnell ignored it all. And he won’t care one bitwe suffer such horrors too. His lelong dream is to unleash the same lunatic experiment here.Voters, and Labour’s own more moderate MPs, must never give him that chance.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: its simply sickening to spend 4bn abroad on dubious foreign aid projects
story: But it is simply sickening to spend £billion abroad upgrading road and rail schemes and urban infrastructure.Look at the appalling state of OUR roads, needing a £billion fix of their own. Look at our shambolic rail system and its creaking, crumbling infrastructure overseen by state-run Network Rail.Look at our public finances, our deficit, our gargantuan debt. Look at the local councils facing bankruptcy.Listen to the Government, now facing a headache over Universal Credit, insisting every penny must be made to count.We are entitled to expect decent public services infor our taxes. What justication can there be for hiving off billions from them to improve transport systems in Pakistan Or in India, which has billions for a fleet of new warships and a space programme but needs the British public’s generosity to mend its roads It is insane. The consequence of an idiotic law which compels us to donate billions every year no matter how dire our finances or how spurious the cause.The Sun is all for helping the genuinely needy. But not for foolish virtue-signalling on the world stage.It is an abuse of public funds and a cast-iron election loser.THERESA May must find the cash to help those losing out in the sht to Universal Credit.The new scheme DOES work well for many. It is far simpler and, crucially, incentivises work. But cuts by former Chancellor George Osborne are now biting too hard. Some claimants face a severe blow to their income.If the PM is genuinely “listening to concerns”, as she says, then good.Voters generally back less generous benefit payments. Especially compared with the absurd levels under the last Labour Government, which fostered idleness and trapped huge numbers permanently on the dole. But Brits are famously keen on fair play too.They won’t support families being stripped of money through no fault of their own.KIDS don’t need a smartphone in class. It can only wreck their concentration and harm their education.How can they learnthey’re too busy sneaking a look at Snapchat How can they learnthey’re too busy sneaking a look at Snapchat Other countries have done already.But generations of pupils survived without them. And the downside is too great.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: princess eugenie wedding itv katie glass comment
story: But this time there was no argument over the TV remote. The BBC and Sky turned down the chance to show it, leaving Eamonn Holmes and Ruth Langsford on ITV’s This Morning to oversee the whole shebang.It meant coverage was relaxed, which suited Eamonn and Ruth, who admitted they had no idea how to pronounce the bride’s name.When we cut to Windsor, guests were thin on the ground. Just a smattering of overzealous royalists and tourists waving flags.“It’s not the same as Meghan and Harry,” Eamonn was forced to admit.As we waited for the couple to arrive, Alison Hammond was sent to interview superfans who had waited since am. Only they didn’t seem to know why. Asked what she loved about Eugenie and Jack, one royalist shrugged: “I don’t really know anything about them.”Another, Anita Atkinson, , was a bit more fun and “really, really, really excited” about the wedding.She then ulged a wee bit more than we wanted to know by confessing: “When you get to a certain age things happen, you know.”Even the royal pundits ITV had wangled on struggled to convey much enthusiasm for the whole thing.“Remember that she is a blood Princess,” one said.“She’s ninth in line to the throne and Harry is only sixth, so there’s not a lot of dference,” another offered.In an interview before the shindig, the couple promised Ruth and Eamonn a wave. But it didn’t happen.A disappointed Eamonn wailed: “He promised us a wave, Ruth. He lied!”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: democratic football lads alliance march turns violent as far right supporters clash with cops
story: Dozens of DFLA protesters were seen fighting with police officers, with one threatening a cop and screaming “I’ll kill you”, according to reports.The clash – which resulted in at least one arrest – came despite the alliance telling its supporters to remain “respectful and decent” during today’s demonstration.Several hostile-looking men had to be held back from joining in the fighting by their friends, said the Press Association.The Anti-Fascist Network said that its counter demonstration to show opposition to the event resulted in the DFLA being “sandwiched” by their black-clad supporters and police following the alliances march.On Facebook, DFLA march organisers explained they were protesting against ing jihadists, thousands of AWOL migrants, rape gangs and groomers, and veterans treated like traitors.Prior to todays event, they had urged people to “take to the streets to highlight the cost of austerity, the uncontrolled kne crime, the plight of victims of rape and abuse and PTSDthat our unaccountable government is responsible for.“We need to be aware that the left are going to try and goad you, to provoke you to violence. Remember,you respond you may as well hand them a child to be abused, so stand strong, stand proud, do not give into them.“We will have the attention of the media with us, this is our chance to influence the nation, to get Government to sit up and take note. We are the kingmakers.“This will be the day we saved our country from Westmonster.”Hundreds of DFLA supporters were walking from Park Lane to Whitehall before some of them started to push through their police escorts, reported the PA.Peter Mantell, , attending the demonstration from Crayford, told the PA: I detest some of the people Im walking with. A lot of them hate people because of the colour of their skin.Im a lefty. But I believe we should have a voice against the people who want to hurt everyone and cause harm.He also admitted that he was a supporter of former English Defence League leader Tommy Robinson.Many demonstrators could be heard chanting whose streets  Our streets  as they marched down Pall Mall.Scores of police on horseback and wearing riot gear tried to control the swelling groups with police vans trying to block them in, as some yelled at them for alleged inaction against paedos and grooming gangs, reported MailOnline.One person watching the clashes described it on Twitter as an “absolute scruffy shambles. Their [DFLA] pathetic march blocked by a much larger anti-fascist turnout”.Another man tweeted about seeing “intense scenes at Trafalgar Square. As a bystander, without any kind of political stand, I’ve just been verbally abused by a man with a shaved head, brandishing a St George’s cross flag and dragging a small child round.”Prior to the event, the politan police said it had imposed conditions upon marches and rallies being planned by the DFLA, and also upon the anti-fascist counter demonstration.This stipulated that protesters must start their march at Park Lane, and continue along Piccadilly, St Jamess Street, Pall Mall, Trafalgar Square and ending at Whitehall.The force asked attendees to conduct themselves peacefully, whatever your view... failure to adhere to these conditions may lead to arrest and prosecution.” said that thousands of people attended the event.

title: panic rooms new york mansions ms 13 gang
story: Eastern parts of Long Island – including The Hamptons – have long attracted the rich and famous, and are filled with swanky restaurants and plush homes.But many homeowners are now so terried by rising crime that they are turning their homes into fortresses equipped with bulletproof glass, weaponry and panic rooms.John Catsimatidis who has a holiday home in East Quogue, said: “I sleep with a gun underneath my pillow. A Walther PPK S, the same one James Bond carried.“[My we] Margo prefers a shotgun.“Although, once, she thought she heard something, got the shotgun out and shot through the door.”The billionaire and his family, like others in the Hamptons, are shaken up over concerns that the vicious Salvadorian gang MS- is too close for comfort.In April, members of the gang massacred four young men behind a football pitch on the island.And in , a man with MS- connections broke into a Southampton home and sexually assaulted a woman.Last year, Southampton Town Police Chief Steven Skrynecki publicly expressed concern that the gang might spread further east.When he deployed police equipped with anti-terrorism gear, including automatic weapons, along the perimeters of summer  charity galas, locals took note.One Southampton homeowner, who asked to remain anonymous, recently outfitted her pad with bulletproof glass and hidden cameras throughout.She said: “[MS- is] in Suffolk County. What’s an hour car ride  They are near.”She’s not alone in her concern.Gary Blum is president of Armored Entry, a company that installs bullet-proof, super-secure windows and doors.He said: “The home-security business is very event- and news-driven.“We get business when there is a tremendous amount of fear being generated.”Blum’s products aren’t cheap, starting at £, for a single window “that you can beat with a sledgehammer without making a dent”.But the high price might actually be a selling point.Panic room installer Chris Cosban said: “The big thing [with homeowners] in the Hamptons is thatsomebody has it, they [all] want it.”His company, Covert Interiors, charges between £, and £, for a standard space.High-tech add-ons, such as fingerprint recognition, cost extra.But that’s nothing compared to the security measures that Al Corbi, president of SAFE , an architecture-focused security firm, has designed for customers.He said of one project: “I finished a system for million .“That sounds like a lot but there is nothing I know of, human or manmade, that could possibly harm this family for three generations, including global nuclear holocaust, a pandemic or a second Ice Age.”He added: “It’s like a Ritz-Carlton underground.” A version of this story originally appeared on New York Post.

title: we dont owe musical genius to the eu
story: Fine, highfalutin words, Bono.But try telling them to the ­millions of young people who are unemployed in Italy, Spain and Greece, the economies of those proud countries dragged down by the dead weight of the euro. And try out the windbag oratory on the .million decent British democrats who voted to leave the European Union, and who have been told ever since that they are racist, ignorant ­bigots who should never be allowed near a polling booth.I like Bono. In person, he is a decent, thoughtful man. His band are not bad. But why do the former rebels of rock music always tug their forelocks to the European Union  Why does everyone in leather trousers act like the EU is an unalloyed good thing  Why does rock music have a blind spot when it comes to Brussels How can Bono, right, possibly mistake Jean-Claude Juncker for Joe Strummer   The EU is the ESTABLISHMENT, man! And the EU is the ­establishment at its most ­unaccountable, undemocratic, incompetent and corrupt.The EU is not a beautul thing, Bono. It is a crumbling ­expansionist empire, rotten to the core, merciless in its opposition to democracy.The EU is a gravy train, Bono, a trough for puffed-up political piggies, a sclerotic body of ­privileged old white men in suits with MEPs who do not have to provide receipts for their £,-a-month expenses. The EU really stinks, Bono.And the music that you and I grew up with — the music we loved, the music U and I were inspired by, the music we placed at the centre of our worlds — was meant to be against this kind of thing. Bono bent the knee to the bullies of Brussels in the same week that Bob Geldof sent a ­letter to Theresa May warning her that Brexit will be the day the music dies.“Imagine Britain without its music,” thundered Geldof’s letter, co-signed by musicians including Sting, Ed Sheeran, Jarvis Cocker and Damon Albarn. “If it’s hard for us, then it’s impossible for the rest of the world. Britain does rule the waves. The airwaves. But Brexit threatens, as it does so much , this vast voice.”But it is simply not true that our country owes its musical genius to the European Union. The golden years of British music were before we joined the EU — when it was still being touted to us as a common market — back in .The Beatles, the Rolling Stones, The Who, The Kinks, Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin all somehow managed to make great music without Brussels. Now Geldof and his co-signatories seriously suggest that British music can’t survive outside the European Union.No doubt the Brexit-loathing Boomtown Rat believes this rubbish but everyone  who signed his Whinge Aid letter should have paused to think before signing. Because by claiming that Brexit will kill British music, Ed Sheeran, Sting and the rest just make themselves look like laughably out-of-touch luvvies. Not a good look for the wild boys of rock ’n’ roll.Geldof is right about one thing — British music has been brilliant for  years because our little country embraced the world.But John Lennon, Jimmy Page, Joe Strummer, Mick Jones, Ray Davies, Robert Plant, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and Pete Townshend opened their ears and their hearts to the sounds coming out of America.The glorious music that smashed down the walls between white music and black music was born in Chicago and Nashville and Detroit and Memphis.  Its roots were in the backwoods of the Deep South and the ­Mississippi Delta, and reached all the way back to Africa. Belgium never came into it, Bob.The Rolling Stones never needed a grant from the EU. They just needed one glimpse of Buddy Holly, one listen to Muddy Waters, one nod from Elvis Presley. British bands changed the world and they sure as hell did it without the help of the European Union. Sorry, Bob. Sorry, Bono. But no British musician in history was ever inspired by the mysterious rhythms coming out of Brussels.PETER JACKSON’S new film, They Shall Not Grow Old, shows painstakingly coloured images from World War One for the very first time.Because we have only experienced World War One in black and white footage and photos, there has always felt like a huge distance between our time and the unimaginable horrors of the trenches.Lord Of The Rings director Jackson has bridged that gap and the results, above, take your breath away. He says: “The war was a colour war. You’re seeing it as they saw it. And they saw it in colour.”World War One never felt closer. And the humour, humanity and courage of the men who fought it has never been more heartbreaking.BEST wishes for the future to Trevor Engelson and his bride Tracey Kurland, who were married in a low-key ceremony in Calornia last weekend.Andyou don’t recognise the names, that is because Mr Engelson has chosen to keep a discreet silence on the subject of his two-year marriage to Meghan Markle.And in an age where every broken relationship is ­dissected on social media, isn’t it refreshing to see a man who can keep a dignied silence “WE lost the match but won the battle,” claimed Conor McGregor after his beating in last weekend’s UFC .  What planet was that victory on then, Conor To the casual fan it looked like McGregor  followed up months of denigrating Khabib Nurmagomedov with a feeble performance in the octagon and a lack of grace in defeat.True, Khabib spoilt his victory by jumping into the crowd to continue the punch-up with McGregor’s corner.  But for the le of me I can’t see how Conor McGregor can claim anything other than unconditional surrender. Neither man brought credit to MMA.There is only one reason why mainstream sports fans have been paying interest to Mixed Martial Arts in recent years and that is Conor McGregor. But after the squalid scenes around Conor v Khabib, many of us will be turning off the MMA.Even Mike Tyson was shocked. And he once bit off part of a man’s ear.WHAT my mum would have found unforgivable about Strictly star Seann Walsh snogging Katya Jones is that it happened when Walsh’s girlfriend, Rebecca Humphries, was home alone on her BIRTHDAY.My mum would never have forgiven that kind of casual cruelty from some curly-haired love rat. And I suspect the great British public will feel the same. But what we call the Strictly curse is really just an office romance that spirals out of control.People get thrown together at work all the time. The dference is that a couple from the accounts department don’t usually spend hours every day rubbing up against each other perfecting their Paso Doble.But the intense, intimate physical contact of doing Strictly makes it certain the curse will strike again.The mystery is why Katya was never led astray by Ed Balls.FEMALE terrorist, married to a British jihadi, claimed a council breached her human rights by not giving her a new home after she turned down seven homes because they were not big enough or not in the right location.Kindly Brent Council also offered her £, to put down a deposit on a home of her own.Are we insane Our welfare state was built to care for the most vulnerable members of our society.Not creatures who would spit on our society’s grave.TINA TURNER is the only female performer who was hotter live than Blondie’s Debbie Harry in her pouting, heavy-lidded prime.So it comes as some surprise to hear Tina say that she never tried to be sexy on stage. “Fishnets are practical,” Tina says primly. “They don’t run. And leather doesn’t show the perspiration on stage or wrinkle. I only wore a mini-dress because everyone knows you can’t dance in a dress that goes past your knee.”OK, Tina, we believe you – even though your practical work clothes launched a million adolescent fantasies. And that was just in my house.DRESSED like a street-walking disco ball, Taylor Swt urges America to go out and vote Democrat in the American mid-term elections.I admire young Taylor but does it never occur to these celebrities that their smug self-importance might possibly be drumming up votes for the other side But where were your sensible shoes WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India. Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India.Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm must secure free trade deal
story: As the Prime Minister heads into the most signicant EU summit, she must secure the Brexit promised to the ­British public.Now is the time to deliver for the United Kingdom on the Conservatives’  General Election manesto promise to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade.It does not get clearer than the pledge: “We will no longer be members of the single market or customs union.”  Our manesto also promised that our laws would be made in the UK and interpreted by judges here, not in Europe. That’s why the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal was not right.Under such a deal, we would be required to follow EU laws under the EU rule book and we would still be subject to the European Court of Justice.We would be out of Europe, yet still run by Europe. Any proposal that is brought forward and put to Parliament needs to take back control of our laws and make sure the European Court has no say over us.  So what should Theresa May do  The answer, once again, is set out clearly in the  Conservative manesto.It says: “We will seek a deep and special partnership including a comprehensive free-trade and customs agreement.”  That’s why the Prime Minister should move on from her Chequers proposal and seek an advanced free-trade deal with the EU. A comprehensive free-trade deal, like the EU’s free-trade deals with Canada and Japan, is what our manesto promises require.Such a deal would ensure we take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade. It would honour the referendum mandate. It would be in line with our manesto commitments. And it would work for the EU too. The Government’s objection to this is the supposed dficulty of keeping an open border in Northern Ireland.For this reason, Government figures claim we cannot seek a trade deal with the EU unless this problem is solved. This is nonsense.Clear proposals have been set out by two former Northern Ireland Secretaries as to how a frictionless border can be maintained under a free-trade agreement. These proposals have been endorsed by former Brexit Secretary David Davis and Good Friday Agreement architect Lord Trimble.Moreover, former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith has set out how we can build on the system of joint border controls at Dover to avoid delays or friction at the UK’s borders — including in Ireland. This would work for the EU’s rules and ensure a positive future relationship going forward.This approach is not simply a bad use of taxpayers’ money. It breaks another manesto pledge.For our  manesto says “it is necessary to agree the terms of our future partnership alongside our withdrawal, reaching agreement on both within two years” of our serving notice to leave the EU. In other words, by the end of March next year.So it is wrong for the Government to agree withdrawal terms without sorting out the full detail of our future relationship. A temporary fix does not honour the referendum mandate, it does not keep our manesto promise and it certainly fails to look after our hard-earned money.Moreover, would this temporary fix really be temporary  Just ask the people of Norway how such a deal turned out for them. In  they signed the European Economic Area Agreement. They were told by the EU their sovereignty would be respected. Yet  years later, this “temporary” arrangement has become permanent.Meanwhile, the cost has increased ten-fold and nearly , EU directives and regulations have been implemented through Norway’s EEA agreement.Our Government should fear to tread such a dangerous path. Voters will not tolerate any “temporary” arrangement becoming permanent. They would see it as a betrayal. People voted to leave the EU because they wanted change. They believed in Britain and the land of opportunity we can build. They voted to take back control of our laws, money, borders and trade.The Conservative manesto promised that we would leave the EU altogether. That we would seek a free-trade deal and a new national future.Now is the time for the Government to honour the referendum mandate and the Conservative manesto by seeking a free­-trade deal with the EU that enables Britain to become an economic powerhouse in the decades to come.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gangs put witnesses addresses and statements on twitter to intimidate them
story: The crooks are legitimately shown papers by their lawyers but then photograph them.Seven such statements about murders, knings and jail attacks have appeared on a Twitter account over the past year.A number have the hashtag #Snitchsquad.Some gangsters threaten witnesses from behind bars with smuggled-in phones.Crime expert Dr Simon Harding told Channel ’s Dispatches: “It’s a way of communicating they have power and authority over an area or iniduals.Police aren’t fully on top of this yet.”Abraham Badru, , was shot dead this year in Hackney, East London, nine years after he foiled a gang rape and helped jail the attackers.Mum Ronke believes it is why he was killed.The gunman remains at large.Det Supt Mike West said: “We need to improve our ability to scan for risk on social media.We’re seeing a transition from online content into offline violence.”Twitter refuses to axe the account outing witnesses.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: craig mackey 12 times more pension keith palmer
story: Deputy Met commissioner Sir Craig Mackey was accused of cowardice for locking himself in his car in the Westminster attack.Based on current earnings he could pocket up to £,-a-year, or £, a month, when he retires in December.Michelle Palmer, , is believed to be left with £, a year widow’s pension.Retired Det Chief Insp Mick Neville, who spent  years in the Met, said last night: “When the public look at PC Palmer’s bravery to stop a terrorist, then the contribution of Mr Mackey they will judge themselves who deserves the most pension.”Sir Craig, , was yards from unarmed PC Palmer, , when he was stabbed by jihadi Khalid Masood last March. Sir Craig was acting Met Commissioner at the time, earning £, a year.He will avoid any potential disciplinary action when he leaves after  years’ service.Insp Matt Webb, of the Sussex Police Federation, said his actions on that day were unforgivable and called for him to be stripped of his knighthood.Online pranksters altered a pic of Sir Craig getting his gong, replacing it with a white feather — a symbol of cowardice.Met chief Cressida Dick said: “Sir Craig had absolutely no opportunity to save PC Palmer.”And coroner Mark Lucraft QC told last week’s inquest Sir Craig couldn’t have done anything to stop the attack.Scotland Yard’s counter-terror chief Neil Basu branded the cowardice claims “abhorrent”.Sir Craig said he remained in the vehicle with two civilian colleagues because they had no protective equipment or a radio.He tried to get out of the car but was advised by an officer on guard at the site to leave.Michelle Palmer says her husband “was left at a vulnerable location with no protection to die.” He was carrying only a truncheon and CS spray.She should have received a lump sum of £, from the Met for his death. It is understood that they are considering a civil action for damages.Masood’s rampage left five dead. Friday’s inquest verdict at the Old Bailey found he was lawfully killed.A Met spokeswoman declined to comment on the pensions.LIONS led by donkeys. It was said of the Tommies in WW. And it’s true, it seems, for the frontline coppers of the politan Police.It was bad enough that “white feather” top cop Sir Craig Mackey locked himself in his car as Khalid Masood wreaked havoc around Parliament.But to see the size of his potential ­pension compared with the rank and file’s is sickening. Boardroom bobbies have closed ranks around Mackey, saying he had no choice but to keep out of danger. title: grandma move out mouldy cupboard
story: Sue Wheeldon, , says the faulty service cupboard in her flat has been dripping water for over a year and has made her sick because of the terrible smell it makes.The furious resident, who has diabetes, says that whenever she turns the heating on the stench of mould and damp makes anyone inside cough as the wreaking stink spreads throughout the property.She also said that her granddaughter, who stays with her every weekend, suffers from asthma which gets aggravated by the intolerable stench.Sue told the Hull Daily Mail:It only smells when I put the heating on so I darent put it on.I feel so ill, I am cold all the time and I cant stay in there with no heating.The disgusting odour from the cupboard ultimately forced her to leave her home this week and stay with a friend.She first discovered the problem when Yorkshire Water got in touch with her last year to tell her that her water bill leaped from £ to £ a month which she put down to the flowing leak.But after complaining repeatedly to Hull City Council about the problem the cupboard is still leaking.The local authority has now apologised and said it will re-plaster the affected area, but Sue doesnt think that will solve the problem.Shes repeatedly tried stemming the flow by putting towels down but the water always seeps through, eventually covering the ceiling and floor.The grandma wants a new pipe fitting as shes had to spend money replacing damaged flooring because of the problem, which she says should have been sorted ages ago.Hull City Council has says its truly sorry for the problems that Sue has had to live with and will try and repair the leak next week.

story: Corey Sharpling, , was on his way to work at McDonalds in Camrarthen, West Wales, when he took a closer look at the rescue operation on the A.He watched council workers chop up a tree which had fallen and blocked the road, even causing a lorry to be swept into a nearby river.But he was struck by a huge landslide of rocks and earth falling onto the road.A witness said: There was a loud rumble as some of the valley side slipped down the hillside.This poor lad was hit by the full force of it, he didnt stand a chance. the Met Office added: Theres a cool clear start for many parts of the UK on Monday, and actually for much of the UK its a dry fine and sunny day to boot.Storm Callum caused rivers to burst their banks parts of south Wales recording -mm of rain.Wales usually sees an average rainfall in October of .mm and a monthly average of .mm.Despite the storms, temperatures have been much higher for this time of story: Mrs May could be hit with a wave of resignations this weekpro-Brexit Cabinet ministers decide they cant get behind her ideas.On Tuesday the PM will hold another crunch meeting of her Cabinet, after a breakthrough failed last week at an emergency meeting.And a so-called pizza club will be held in Parliament tomorrow to discuss Brexit negotiations and their response to Mrs Mays strategy, the Mail on Sunday reported.One source said: We have managed to keep it very secret. because it would fuel the case for Scottish independence.Stewart Jackson, ex-chief of staff to former Brexit secretary David Davis, said it was “quite possible” another Cabinet minister could follow the example of his former boss and resign.Whips have threatened MPs with an early general electionthey dont back the Prime Ministers agreement with Brussels.But many fear it will allow Jeremy Corbyn to slip in to No.Last time Mrs May called a snap election she lost seats - This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.”And MPs are said to have handed in more letters saying they have no confidence in the Prime Minister.Several more were handed in to the chairman of the Tory  committee in the past few weeks - and only four more could be needed to launch a vote of no confidence in the PM.If she loses that vote, then a leadership challenge could be called.Meanwhile, Labour MPs have today broken ranks to say they will back Mrs Mays Chequers dealit means avoiding a No Deal scenario.Caroline Flint, along with fellow MPs Gareth Snell and Ruth Smeeth, said they could vote with the Government when the deal comes to Parliament.Don Valley MP Ms Flint said today: “I believethere is a reasonable deal that stops us crashing out with no deal, we shouldn’t rule it out.”The Independent reports there could be up to  who would back the plans in the Commons.Last night a leaked memo revealed that a secret deal was already sealed - before the Cabinet had seen it.It boasts: “Deal made, nothing made public .” It says the plan will be rubber-stamped by the Government... before being announced amid fanfares in Brussels.But DUP boss Arlene Foster is said to think that a No Deal option is now the most likely option.Leaked emails to the Observer say that she is ready for us to leave with no agreement with Brussels, after ongoing tussles over the Northern Irish border.“AF [Arlene Foster] said the DUP were ready for a no-deal scenario, which she now believed was the likeliest one, they said.However, No denied it was all wrapped up and negotiations were ongoing.The PM faces a crunch EU summit with other leaders of the  nations later this week.

title: starving dog skinny bones north shields car park
story: The neglected Staffordshire Bull Terrier, named Ayma by vets caring for her, was discovered in the early hours of Friday morning by a member of the public walking in North Shields, Tyne and Wear.The RSPCA are now looking into the incident in which the poor Staffy was so seriously underweight that all of her bones were visible through her skin.RSPCA inspector Cathy Maddison, who is now investigating the appalling case, says no amount of experience working in animal rescue can prepare you for seeing a dog so horrendously starved.She said on Friday: I dont know how she is still alive and what is even more heartbreaking is just how lovely and friendly she is, despite what she has been through.She is now on fluids at the vets and has been given some much-needed food.Sadly, it is really touch and go for her as she is so emaciated so it’s not knownshe will pull through the night.Unfortunately, Cathys fears were confirmed when vets took the dficult decision to put Ayma to sleep last night after her appalling condition deteriorated.The Staffy wasnt microchipped but was believed to be about four years old and was found covered in fleas.The man that found Ayma told Cathy he was on his way to a job interview when he came across the poor pup.He wrapped her up in a towel to keep her warm and contacted the RSPCA to get urgent help, but ultimately her sickness was too far gone for vets to save her.Earlier this year, The Sun and the RSPCA put out a call for people to come forward and adopt puppies and dogs that have been abandoned or abused across the UK.Tens of thousands of dogs are abandoned in Britain every year for a iety of reasons ranging from poverty, human sickness, and the puppy trade churning out designer dogs.

title: universal credit sanctions under 30s iain duncan smith
story: New figures show that more than  per cent of penalties under the Governments controversial new system land on Brits under .Campaigners have demanded that the system - which has been beset with problems so far - be halted while the issues are fixed, or even scrapped altogether.Today the architect of the scheme, Iain Duncan Smith, said ministers would be betraying the Just About Managing Britsit didnt help plough extra money into the scheme.He told Skys Sophy Ridge on Sunday programme: Theresa May stood on the steps of Downing Street and said I want to look after those who are just about managing.Universal Credit is the single best system to get to those who are just about managing... we need to put the money in. Im asking him to do that. Nobody should lose at all.Ministers have reversed some of the cuts to the welfare budget - but Brits are still set to lose out under the new regime.Today  Tories signed a campaign urging Theresa May to change rack and reverse the planned cutts.Research from Labour showed that out of , decisions to sanction Brits under Universal Credit, , were for those under  - and a fth were for claimts who were aged  and .Most sanctions are handed out because claimants failed to attend scheduled appointments.Labour’s Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood stormed: Rather than supporting young people into secure, well paid jobs, the Tories are hitting them with sanctions.“Universal Credit is causing poverty and hardship wherever its rolled out, especially for young people.The party wants to reviewed the whole system to seeits fit for purpose - after reports that hundreds of people have lost money on the new system.Its also been attacked for taking weeks for claimants to get their first payment, and for stopping domestic abuse victims from leaving their partners as benefits are now only paid into one account per family.A DWP spokesperson said today: Sanctions are only used in a very small percentage of cases when people fail to meet their agreed commitments infor benefits.Universal Credit provides additional, tailored support to help people into work, and evidence shows that as a result people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.IF youre experiencing trouble applying for your Universal Credit, or the payments just dont cover it, here are your options:Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently , or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Last week it was revealed that millions of families could be left up to £ a week worse off when the new system is rolled out to everyone on benefits next year.But some , are set to benefit and could get up to £, extra as officials are able to tell who is missing out, Theresa May also revealed this week.Ex-PMs John Major and Gordon Brown have warned that the issue could be as bad the poll tax for the party, and must be looked at again.And unhappy Tories are demanding that extra money be ploughed into it to stop that happening.It has been speculated that Philip Hammond is mulling cancelling the planned tax break for low earning Brits to try and rescue the system.Mr Duncan Smith added today: If you put the money into UC allowances, nearly  per cent of the money goes straight to the poorest four percentiles - its a no brainer really.But Health Secretary Matt Hancock today insisted that Universal Credit was working - and he hadnt had any complaints about it in his area.The majority of people prefer being on UC, he said, insisting that when people are migrated onto the new benefit we put a new £billion package to make sure people arent worse off.The DWP has been approached for comment.

title: pregnant woman lost baby says unborn child saved her life
story: Louise Abbott, , was  weeks pregnant when Leroy Margolis, , veered across the road and ploughed into her car.The nursery worker, from Braintree, Essex, was saved from suffering fatal injuries due to the baby bump taking the impact.But tragically baby Layla died from a fractured skull and heartbroken Louise had to give birth to her because she was too injured for a cesarean.Louise has now received an undisclosed financial settlement to pay for the specialist therapies and support she is continuing to receive following her ordeal.She said: The crash, finding out Layla had died and then giving birth to her is something that will stay with me for the rest of my le.It is almost impossible to put into words the effect it has had on me and [husband] Laurence.We go through a full mix of emotions each day knowing that Layla should still be part of our family and thinking what , even though the events were clearly out of our control.Louise was being driven to a wedding party on October , , in Cambridgeshire when Margolis overtook a lorry at mph.He lost control at a staggered junction and smashed into the car Louise was travelling in with a witness describing his driving as suicidal.The former Lloyds banker was caged for two years last year after being convicted of causing serious injury by dangerous driving.Louise was later told by medics she may never have children because of one of her oies had been rendered useless as a result of her injuries.But her and husband Laurence, , welcomed a healthy daughter named Avery last year.At first we felt guilty because of Layla but Avery was not a replacement for Layla.Layla will also be part of our family. Avery will know all about her big sister but we will always be sad that they never got to meet each other and grow up with one another, forming the bonds and friendships sisters should.Louise said previously: Our babyhad little nails and hair and she was fully formed, fully developed, ready to be born the next day.But now, we know that without I might not be alive had it not been for the accident- and little Avery wouldnt have been born, and I wouldnt be here to have more children in the future.Because of the extra blood I had in me due to my pregnancy, and because Layla cushioned the bump, I wouldnt have lived had it not been for her.I will never forget those words, Im sorry, your baby has died.The mum has joined their legal team at Irwin Mitchell in using Baby Loss Awareness Week to speak out about the support available to other families who have experienced the heartbreak of losing a child.Tracey Storey, Partner and specialist serious injury lawyer at the firm, said: It may have been two years since Layla’s death but the pain and loss that Louise and Laurence continue to experience is still understandably extremely raw.While no amount of money will ever make up for what has happened, we are pleased that Louise has been able to access the support she needs so she, Laurence and their family can try and look to the future the best they can while never forgetting Layla.

title: emily thornberry accuses bbc journalist
story: NewsEmily Thornberry accuses BBC journalist of swallowing No propaganda in live TV Brexit clashThe Shadow Foreign Secretary turned her fire on TV host Andrew Marr as he dared to question her about Labours stance on leaving the EUShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video emily-thornberry-in-brexit-clash-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Labours Emily Thornberry today accused a BBC journalist of swallowing Number  propaganda in a live TV clash over Brexit .The Shadow Foreign Secretary turned her fire on TV host Andrew Marr as he dared to question her about Labours stance on leaving the EU.The direct attack comes after Donald Trump branded the media fake news and Jeremy Corbyn took up the US Presidents language, saying in August: Most of our citizens think our newspapers churn out fake news day in, day out.Mr Marr was asking what Labours stance will be when MPs are told to vote for or against Theresa Mays Brexit plan in the House of Commons, probably in late November. But some Labour MPs, including Caroline Flint, look set to back the plan anyway - because they fear rejecting it would hurl Britain into a more damaging No Deal Brexit. He has not spelt out exactly how this would happen, and Tory MPs claim it wont.Mr Marr asked Ms Thornberry: To be crystal clear,Theresa May brings back this kind of deal and MPs are told it’s this or the chaos of no deal, Labour MPs will still vote against her She replied: That is a  choice. Labours six tests for the final Brexit dealDoes it ensure a strong and collaborative future relationship with the EU  Does it deliver the “exact same benefits” as we currently have as members of the Single Market and Customs Union  Does it ensure the fair management of migration in the interests of the economy and communities  Does it defend rights and protections and prevent a race to the bottom  Does it protect national security and our capacity to tackle cross-border crime Does it deliver for all regions and nations of the UK

title: more 160 celebrities nominated honours
story: NewsMore than  celebrities nominated for honours have been secretly blacklisted over tax dodgingChecks are carried out to ensure The Queen does not end up embarrassed by who she honoursShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than  celebrities nominated for gongs have been secretly blacklisted for dodging tax. Checks are carried out to ensure The Queen does not end up embarrassed by who she honours. Now the taxman has confirmed that  top TV, film, music and sports stars and other public figures have been flagged as high or medium risk. Figures revealed under the Freedom of Information Act showed that  people recommended for an honour have been flagged as red or high risk since January . Red warnings are assigned to those who use avoidance schemes on a serial basis, are under criminal investigation for tax fraud or are involved in offshore evasion.  Meanwhile, a further  people have been given an amber or medium risk rating, according to The Sunday Times. The amber category included people participating in one or more avoidance schemes, those subject to a non-criminal investigation or household names who had shown frequent delays in submitting tax s. They are among thousands of candidates to have been vetted by HM Revenue and Customs to check their finances are above board. Last month, it was revealed that HMRC has been alerting the Cabinet Office to iniduals involved in controversial tax schemes. The secretive process sees a low, medium, or high risk rating assigned to prospective nominees to minimise the risk thathave behaved in ways likely to bring the system into disrepute.  The figures also showed , people were said to be considered low risk or rated green. The low risk rating applied to those with minor issues with the taxman or those whose affairs amounted to acceptable tax planning. The Government has previously said the vetting process was a matter of longstanding policy to protect the integrity of the system. Experts backed the taxmans vetting of honours, but added that they were surprised how many candidates were having their tax affairs scrutinised. About , people a year usually receive honours. But last year only around  people were vetted. Richard Murphy, the academic and tax campaigner, said he was surprised by the number of people being vetted. He added that the figure added weight to those who think HMRC spends too much time going after small businesses and not enough time on the very wealthy.

story: NewsNo Deal Brexit now the likeliest option as David Davis demands Cabinet insurrection with just days to goTheresa May faces a vicious pincer movement from Tories and the DUP as she faces leadership threats, a resignations "landslide" and a make-or-break EU dinner. Her key DUP allies have claimed No Deal Brexit is now the most likely outcome - while Tory David Davis demands a full-blown Cabinet insurrection against the PM. Mrs May now faces a vicious pincer movement from Brexiteers and the DUP who are both furious about her proposed plan for leaving the EU on  March . It comes amid a torrent of new claims in Sunday newspapers that she is just a few MPs from a leadership challenge - and a mass Cabinet resignation could tip her over the edge.  In summary - among the reports that have emerged today are:No Deal Brexit is the most likely outcome, the DUP believe Tory David Davis has urged a Cabinet uprising against Theresa May She has been warned of a resignations landslide and a leadership contest MPs are branding her deal lipstick on a pig and a bag of vomit One Brexiteer believes he may be being bugged by MIMrs May will meet  EU leaders on Wednesday for a make-or-break dinner to nail down an agreement ahead of votes in the EU and the UK Parliament. But Brussels is still demanding customs checks on food and goods between Northern Ireland and Great Britain, which has infuriated the DUP. DUP leader Arlene Foster reportedly said a no-deal Brexit was now the most likely outcome after her talks with chief negotiator Michel Barnier ended without agreement. The comment was revealed in e-mails leaked to the Observer. One said the DUP were ready for a no-deal scenario, which she now believed was the likeliest one.  No Deal would cancel  international trade deals, force Brits to renew their passports, introduce months of paperwork for travelling pets and more. Experts say it would cost the economy billions. But Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson has also voiced fears over the planned compromised. PoliticsHome today reports she has written to Theresa May warning of the consequences of treating Northern Ireland dferently from the rest of the UK. Meanwhile a separate row has exploded with Tory Brexiteers over a backup plan that they say would destroy the ambition of Brexit. Mrs May is thought to be looking at dropping a December  end date for her backstop, which would temporarily keep the whole of the UK in the EU customs union. The plan would prevent a hard border in Northern Ireland while a better deal is found. But Brexiteers warn it will ban the UK from striking new trade deals around the world. Today, former Brexit Secretary David Davis warned the completely unacceptable plan will keep the UK shackled to EU rules by at least .  Writing for the Sunday Times, Brexiteer ringleader Mr Davis declared it was time for Cabinet ministers to exert their collective authority. Challenged by the BBC, Health Secretary Matt Hancock refused three times to say there would be a set end date for a backstop. Instead he said: There are dferent ways of ensuring something will be time limited. One senior Brexiteer warned there would be a landslide of resignations and its overMrs May proceeds with her plan. Cabinet Brexiteers Esther McVey , Andrea Leadsom and Penny Mordaunt are said to be considering their position.  The Mail on Sunday reported Ms Leadsom, Theresa Mays former Tory leadership rival, is preparing to lead secretive pizza plot meetings with allies in the coming week to decide her next move. Ten Cabinet ministers will refuse to back the plan without a specic plan for how the UK can leave the customs union, the Sundayreports. Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary, is said to have confronted Theresa May in a meeting this week by alluding to the motto of putting lipstick on a pig. According to the Sunday Times, he said the plan would be little better than third country status with lipstick on it.  Angry Tory MPs warned the Sunday Times ministers have been warned theyll need to resignthey want a shot at the leadership. One fumed: We are all appalled and disgusted. Theyll come out of that meeting and start to sell another bag of vomit. Theyve been weaklings. Tory backbencher Andrea Jenkyns went public with the warning today on Twitter . She wrote: It is better to go down fighting and honouring the democratic decision of our British people than to be long remembered for waving a white flag and surrendering to EU demands. All Brexiteers in govenrment and on the backbenches - its time to Stand Up For Brexit and finally Chuck Chequers.  Up to  Tory MPs are said to have written letters of no confidence in Theresa May - just four short of the number needed to trigger a full leadership contest. David Davis and Boris Johnson are both reported to be standing by for bids for Nothe situation tips over the edge - though the two men appear to have fallen out. Brexiteer Iain Duncan Smith, a former Tory leader, said he would vote against any customs backstop plan without an end date - and warned Theresa May might face some resignations from her Cabinet. When you get to the point where you no longer agree on a fundamental issue, its probably time you found yourself on the backbenches, he said. Its up to people to do that themselves.  Meanwhile  Tory MPs including Mr Davis and Jacob Rees Mogg signed a letter attacking the government over its Brexit forecasts. The letter to Chancellor Philip Hammond challenged him to release the full details of the cross-Whitehall Brexit analysis which forecast GDP growth would be . percentage points lower over  years in No Deal. Former minister Steve Baker said: After several rounds of Project Fear, the reputation of government economic analysis is rock bottom. Its therefore time to reveal Governments full working out for close scrutiny in the public interest. But in a boost for Theresa May, Labour MP Caroline Flint said she and other MPs from her party would support a reasonable dealone comes back to Parliament. This appears to contradict Labours leadership who have said a deal will only be backedit meets six stringent - and many believe now unmeetable - tests. Ms Flint said: Why would you stand along Boris Johnson or Jacob Rees-Mogg who want us to crash out without a deal  Thats the choice.

title: theresa walloped parliament over austerity
story: NewsopinionTheresa May walloped in Parliament over austerity as Jeremy Corbyn demolishes Prime MinisterMrs May was gutted, demolished, ruined, schooled – take your pick. This came about because Mr Corbyn attacked with questions on austerityShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionThis week Jeremy Corbyn did what he’s been threatening to do for a long time"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m not sure anything shows the gap between the Westminster and the wider country than Prime Minister’s Questions. In Parliament we imagine the whole nation grinds to a halt to watch the weekly grilling of the PM. People eagerly gather round radios, workers are called in from the fields, kids stop playing. But, as was pointed out to me this week,at pm on a Wednesday you really want to watch a competition between the red team and the blue team then BBC One’s Bargain Hunt is on. In some ways it’s a shame, though, because this week Jeremy Corbyn did what he’s been threatening to do for a long time. He completely took Theresa May apart. It has been a long road to get to this point for the Labour leader but worth the wait.  Manchester United’s Paddy Crerand once said about George Best that the star’s footwork left opponents with “twisted blood”. And that was the case this week. Mrs May was gutted, shydemolished, ruined, schooled – take your pick. This came about because Mr Corbyn attacked with shyquestions on austerity. And she has no answers. None. Zero. So she evades and ducks and es. To get an answer about austerity you need to talk to the police, firemen, teachers, NHS, armed forces, councils and ask how it’s going for them  Ask the people who are working but are still on their way to food banks how the end of shyausterity is coming along.
