title: musselburgh-racecourse-staff-raise-2000-in-memory-of-former-colleague
story: Graeme Nish, , was the main joinery contractor at the track and the eldest son of long-serving racecourse caretaker Adam and we Elaine, who works in the customer services team.Graeme, of Musselburgh, passed away suddenly on June  and staff raised funds for Pancreatic Cancer UK by taking part in the Edinburgh Half Marathon and k races. Clerk of the course Harriet Graham was joined by marketing manager Aisling Johnston, marketing assistant Maiti Stirling, hospitality executive Grace Richardson, corporate hospitality manager Emma Bidie and her husband Jeremy.Aisling said: ldquoGraeme was a wonderful person to have around the racecourse, he really loved his job and is he is sadly missed by us all. Some of us have never taken part in a race like this before but we were all fully committed. If we can raise a few pounds for pancreatic cancer research in Graemersquos memory then it will be well worth the effort and the training.To donate, go to www.justgiving companyteams MusselburghRacecourse

title: man-targeted-two-musselburgh-businesses
story: Peter Rodgers, of Edinburghrsquos Parkhead Avenue, forced open a locked office door at Musselburghrsquos Costa Coffee outlet and searched lockers within the staff office. He then moved on to the nearby Poundstretcher store on High Street, where he forced open a locked warehouse door and hid from staff.Rodgers was later discovered and confronted by a member of staff and went on to shout, swear and threaten to assault the employee. The -year-old pleaded guilty to all three offences ndash which took place on October  last year ndash during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.He also admitted to a further two offences on the same date of possessing a kne at Musselburgh police station and to assaulting a police officer by spitting on him at St Leonardrsquos police station in Edinburgh.Sherf Donald Corke granted Rodgers bail and deferred sentence till November .

title: community-to-have-its-say-on-how-70000-is-spent
story: Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell MSP visited The Brunton on Tuesday to announce the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Funding for  , with the Musselburgh Area Partnership to receive pound,.This will be supplemented by pound, from the area partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to a iety of local priorities and initiatives in Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig, Carberry and Old Craighall.Ms Campbell said: ldquoThe Community Choices Fund puts decisions about how we invest in communities into the hands of the people who live and work in them. This way of directly involving people is going from strength to strength, establishing itself firmly in Scotland.ldquoTackling poverty and community empowerment are two key priorities for this government. We know that communities are best placed to address the inequalities in their own areas and therefore know what improvements can be made.And she added: ldquoIrsquom pleased that there are so many organisations that will benefit from this funding. Making this announcement during Challenge Poverty Week highlights how everyone in the community can play their part when it comes to tackling poverty.The area partnershiprsquos successful bid for funding follows on from its Your Voice, Your Choice enterprise last year.At that time, it received pound, inCommunity Choices Funding for an initiative aimed at young people.Representatives from local schools voted for the youth projects they wished to see receive the cash aid, which also included pound, from the area partnership.During Tuesdayrsquos visit to Musselburgh, Ms Campbell got the chance to hear from two of the successful recipients: the Plastics Police, a group of Stoneyhill Primary School youngsters who secured funding to buy promotional material to raise awareness of the risk to people, animals and aquatic le from dumping plastics which end up in the ocean and Musselburgh Grammar School pupil Esraa Al Dabbas, who was sponsored by the Syrian support officer at East Lothian Council to develop a Freedom Youth Club for those new to the community.The new tranche of Community Choices Funding saw  community groups across Scotland sharing more than pound, to host events and give people a direct voice in how funds should be invested on priorities in their areas.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoI am delighted that Ms Campbell chose to visit the Musselburgh Area Partnership to announce the funding.ldquoIt was an amazing opportunity for some of the young people involved in the project to speak to the Cabinet Secretary, and for Ms Campbell to see first-hand the amazing work being done by young people in the Musselburgh area as a result of our Participatory Budgeting initiative Your Voice, Your Choice.Stuart Baxter, Musselburgh area manager, added: ldquoWe are now working on this yearrsquos Participatory Budgeting project that will tackle poverty and inequalities in the Musselburgh area and I am sure by continuing the hard work and commitment the community will help deliver another outstanding success.He said a working group and ldquostringent guidelines would have to be set up to progress the townrsquos second Your Voice Your Choice event.He added that other agencies, such as the Citizens Advice Bureau and Poverty Commission, would also be brought on-board.The Scottish Government has set aside pound. million to increase the numbers of people involved in making decisions about investment in their local areas.In  , the Community Choices Fund helped more than , people vote for the things that mattered to them in their community.

title: woman-is-found-crying-for-help-in-tranent
story: Martin Ellard had been socialising and drinking with partner at his Carlaverock Avenue home when ldquoa prolonged argument was said to have broken out between the pair.Neighbours heard shouting and screaming coming from within the property, while they also heard a woman ldquoscreaming and crying.His partner was then forced to run into the street where she was found to be ldquocrying for help following the altercation with Ellard in July this year.A passer-by saw Ellard telling her to get back inside the property but the man intervened by askingshe needed help before calling the police.Police officers arrived at about .pm to find the woman still out in the street where she was described as being ldquoupset and distressed.Ellard, , was then traced and arrested by police at about .am the following day and soon admitted the altercation.The construction worker pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening and abusive manner by shouting, swearing and acting aggressively towards the woman at his home address on July  this year.He also admitted a second similar charge during Tuesdayrsquos appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court when he pleaded guilty to behaving aggressively towards the same woman on February  this year.Fiscal depute Mark Keane said that on this occasion the pair were within Ellardrsquos car at Newbigging, Musselburgh, when ldquoa verbal altercation broke out and the woman felt she could not continue with the relationship.She made her way to Musselburgh Sports Centre to use the gym but when she left the facility later ldquothe accused followed her despite being told ldquoto leave her alone.Again a passer-by heard the woman in distress and called the police.Ellardrsquos solicitor told Sherf Peter McCormack she would reserve her mitigation to the sentencing diet.Sherf McCormack deferred sentence, for the preparation of background reports, to October .

title: jerba-campervans-becomes-one-of-scotlands-first-employee-owned-businesses
story: Jerba Campervans, of Halfland Barns, near North Berwick, was founded by husband-and-we Simon Poole and Cath Brookes in  and focuses in luxury conversions of the VW Transporter T.In January, it became  per owned by its staff.In the months following, the business has experienced an  per cent rise in productivity, with revenue on track to grow  per cent to pound.m for the year.Mr Poole said: ldquoWe employ people who love what they do. As a result, wersquove benefited from amazing loyalty from those who have been instrumental in building the business.ldquoBecoming employee-owned was simply the right thing to do both morally and practically.ldquoOur productivity and growth figures for the year demonstrate what can be achieved with employee ownership.In becoming employee-owned, the two owners transferred all shares into the Jerba Campervans Trust.The trust board is made up of one employee appointed by the directors an employee elected by staff and an external accountant.The co-directors report to the trust board, which ensures the business is being run for the benefit of the employees.Mr Poole said that the change was ldquobenefiting every aspect of the business.He added: ldquoOur staff are more invested in what we do ndash the wind in their sails is not letting up.

title: interim-asbo-issued-against-haddington-resident
story: Lee Rutherford, who is living care of an address in Langriggs, was the subject of a string of complaints stretching back two years, including smoking cannabis in and around the property, arguing, screaming, shouting and banging doors and acting in an aggressive manner ndash all of which caused alarm and distress to residents of the street.Despite repeated warnings, the anti-social behaviour continued and the interim Anti-Social Behaviour Orderwas applied for by East Lothian Council and later granted at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Wednesday .East Lothian Councilrsquos Safer Communities Team worked closely with Police Scotland to compile the dossier of evidence which was used to prepare the case against Mr Rutherford.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe take anti-social behaviour very seriously and it will not be tolerated in East Lothian as it causes a signicant level of disruption, fear and distress to our residents, which we deem unacceptable."Mr Rutherford has a long history of behaving in an anti-social manner which is why the council applied for this interim ASBO."We will take similar action against those who persist in behaving in an unacceptable way.The interim order will prevent Mr Rutherford from behaving in the manner described until November  when the case will call again.At that time, the council will ask the court to grant an ASBO in the same terms as the interim order but for a period of two years.

title: your-chance-to-win-gift-vouchers-by-tasting-food
story: The university is on the lookout for more than  new food tasters to take part in the taste  run by its Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation.They get the chance to try new Scottish food and drinks products, including cakes, bakery, dairy, ready meals and meat products, as well as new food products that have yet to launch.The food  currently attract many retired people from the community, as well as all those who are available to attend the university during weekdays.However, due to a new large-scale project, there is a need for hundreds of new ists who have an interest in food and enjoy sharing opinions on the subject.Vanessa Durney, a food  member from Musselburgh, said: ldquoIrsquove really enjoyed taking part in taste trials as we get the opportunity to taste premium brand products, basic ranges and new products that are in the development phase.ldquoThe taste trials take part in the universityrsquos sensory evaluation suite and we donrsquot see any labelling, branding, production information or packaging. This helps ensure there are fewer influencing factors and that we provide an unbiased response. Peoplersquos palate and opinions can dfer wildly, so the conversations after the tastings are always very interesting.No previous experience is necessary to take part in the sessions but all participants should be over  and should not have any dietary restrictions or food allergies. They are rewarded with a choice of gt vouchers from either John Lewis or Amazon ndash between pound and pound ndash as a thank you for attending.Panels run throughout the year and ists are free to apply for as many or as few sessions as they wish.For more information or to sign up, email Lucy MacLellan at consumer@qmu.ac.uk

title: tranent-woman-caused-disturbance-after-accusing-girlfriend-of-being-unfaithful
story: Jacqueline Stevenson behaved aggressively, believing that her partner had not been faithful during their relationship.Stevenson grabbed her belongings from the couplersquos home before the pair began struggling with each other as her partner disputed the ownership of the items being taken.Following a physical struggle between the pair, neighbours stepped in to break it up before police were called in.Stevenson pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing, acting in an aggressive manner and struggling with the woman at an address at Potters Path, Tranent, on May  when she appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday.Fiscal depute Anna Robertson told the court that Stevensonrsquos partner was within her Tranent home when she received a phone call which ldquoenraged Stevenson at about .am.The fiscal said that Stevenson began ldquoshouting and swearing before ldquoaccusing her of cheating.The argument between the pair lasted a number of hours and ldquocame to a head when Ms Stevenson picked up items from the locus and began to leave.Her partner was said to have followed Stevenson ldquocrying and saying the items were hers before a struggle ensued between the pair.Neighbours watched on as the couple argued before one neighbour ldquoattempted to break up the struggle.Police were subsequently called in to deal with the situation and Stevenson, , was arrested and charged.Defending solicitor Rebecca Weissgerber said that Stevenson was currently living with her mother and was unemployed.Ms Weissgerber added that the couplersquos relationship was ldquonow at an end after there had ldquobeen some dubiety as to whether [Stevensonrsquos partner] had been faithful.Sherf Adrian Cottam acknowledged Stevensonrsquos lack of previous offending and decided to issue a fine of pound to mark the offence.Sherf Cottam also agreed with the Crownrsquos motion to hand Stevenson a two-year non-harassment order banning her from contacting or approaching her former partner for two years.

title: new-flats-at-former-cockenzie-boatyard-welcome-first-tenants
story: LAR Housing Trust has built  new flats at The Boatyard in its first-ever design and build development.The Boatyard is made up of four onendashbedroom apartments,  two-bed apartments and five two-bed deluxe apartments, all of which have been filled.Mr Stewart said: ldquoThis is an absolutely cracking housing development which adds to the mix here in Cockenzie. Itrsquos on a spectacular site overlooking the harbour.ldquoI was here at the very beginning as they were building and was impressed by the amazing views ndash some of the tenants are going to have a spectacular sight when they open their curtains in the morning.ldquoI want to ensure that every part of Scotland benefits from what is the biggest housing programme in decades. Obviously, East Lothian is a place which will benefit from the amount of investment wersquore making.As a tribute to the former boatyard at the site, a stone carving ndash produced by local sculptor Gardner Molloy ndash has been installed on the harbour-facing side of the building.Andrew Robertson, chairman of LAR, highlighted the carving as ldquoabsolutely critical as it tied into the community that used to work there.He told the Courier: ldquoThis sense of community has been very important here because the design reflects the fishing village boatyard nature of the site.Mr Robertson hoped that, in future, there could even be some kind of small ldquomaritime museum there to ldquoreflect some of that boatbuilding history.Ann Leslie, CEO of LAR, also confirmed that LAR was building another development at nearby Dolphingstone, which will add to the existing East Lothian LAR developments at Macmerry and Pinkie Mains.Mr Robertson said that the majority of new tenants at The Boatyard had come from the local area, adding: ldquoItrsquos lovely. Itrsquos not been explicitly the case. People could have come in from outside.ldquoThe fact that we are actually providing a vehicle for continuity of community is very satisfying. But we wouldnrsquot want to exclude other people who are in need.More than  people from the local area applied for the homes before they had even been advertised, but Mr Robertson was keen to point out that the need for affordable housing was not desperate.ldquoI donrsquot think therersquos a desperate need but itrsquos an expanding local authority economy, he said.ldquoTo call it a desperate demand may be slightly overstating it. There are parts of the country where you could go where there is a desperate need for social housing.ldquoThere is social housing here and therersquos a responsible housing department and good housing associations and we are working very much as part of that mix. I donrsquot think anybody is talking about things being desperate.ldquoThere is a need and itrsquos being met in a controlled and effective way.Ward councillor Neil Gilbert was also present at the handing-over of the keys and told the Courier that the development was ldquoextremely important.He said: ldquoThis is hopefully a step to a lot more of these properties being provided. The level of rent that these facilities house is what East Lothian needs.ldquoThis is a step in the right direction but letrsquos hope itrsquos a springboard for a lot more.ldquoWe need as many affordable properties as we can. When I say affordable, I mean social-rent-affordable. The more we have of those the better.

title: union-launches-petition-in-bid-to-save-toilet-attendants
story: The union has thrown its weight behind staff who are based in public toilets around the county.And it has warned that axing the full-time workers would let standards in the facilities fall and make them a target for ldquovandalism or drug use.East Lothian Council said in July it was considering extending its team of ldquomobile toilet attendants to replace permanent on-site attendants in a bid to save pound,.There are currently seven permanent attendants covering public toilets in Haddington, Musselburgh and North Berwick. In addition, there are half a dozen mobile attendants who provide cover when the permanent attendant is not available.The Unite Scotland petition, which has been launched online at ipetitions, says: ldquoPermanent toilet attendants keep our public toilets safe, clean and accessible for everyone in the community, as well as for tourists.ldquoWithout a permanent attendant to keep watch, it is likely that standards will fall and the toilets could become a target for vandalism or drug use. They could even end up closing altogether.Gillian McKay, Unitersquos regional representative for East Lothian, said public toilets were a ldquobasic need for many.She said: ldquoHaving safe public toilets are essential for many people, including our elderly and those with medical conditions who need to plan a journey around access to a toilet.ldquoBus drivers and lorry drivers also need to be able to find the facilities.ldquoWe understand money needs to be saved but this is a soft target. Our toilets in East Lothian have won awards and the permanent attendants, many of whom are among the lowest paid workers, are dedicated to their role.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIn the challenging financial climate our priority is to seek new ways of maintaining services that meet the needs of residents and visitors while operating within our agreed budget.ldquoMobile toilet attendants already work across the majority of public toilet sites in the county and this is an area that we are exploring.ldquoOur employees are pivotal and as such a service review is being conducted which will include consultation with the unions and staff.The petition is at ipetitions petition save-east-lothian-public-toilets

title: details-of-tom-kitchins-east-lothian-pub-revealed
story: The transformation of the former Golf Inn in Gullane into The Bonnie Badger is well under way, with plans to open in December.Details of the new pub have now been revealed.Michelin star chef Kitchinrsquos we Michaela and dad Ron appeared before East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board to register the change of name for the venue, as well as asking for changes to previous licences.They revealed plans for  bedrooms ndash five of them in a cottage in the gardens of the pub ndash as well as a private dining room which would seat  and double as a conference or meeting room a main dining area outdoor eating area and a herb garden.They also applied for permission to provide off-sales from the pub so that people who buy a bottle of wine are able to take it homethere is some left when they leave.Their representative Caroline Loudon told the board that the Kitchin family had been ldquokeen to come to East Lothian for some time and were expecting a large number of guests who would be using the surrounding golf courses.Applying as well to be allowed to serve breakfast outside from am, she said: ldquoThere will be quite a lot of Americans coming and we would like to be able to offer teas and coffees in the morning, bearing in mind people will have early tee-times.The application to the board said: ldquoThe premises offer a range of other activities including: private dining experiences tastings education tours and learning experiences promotional and media activities fine dining experiences television and filming.It also listed corporate events, private hire, community and charity events, and auctions as possible activities.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, questioned the inclusion of plans for outdoor sports to be held at the pub in the application.However, Mrs Loudon said it was a ldquocatch-all to cover any events, citing an experience in Edinburgh where a premises held a foam party.She said: ldquoLicensing officers came in and said it was not an activity that was on the licence but everyone was foaming by that point.The board approved the iations to the licence, wishing the Kitchins well in their new venture.Councillor Jane Henderson, another ward member, said: ldquoI welcome this development and look forward to the end result. Thank you for making the investment.

title: bridge-in-north-berwick-labelled-an-accident-waiting-to-happen
story: Cash set aside by Cala Homes and currently with East Lothian Council could be used to install lights on the bridge at Ware Road.The bridge is used by motorists and pedestrians ndash and is a key route to school for children going to and from the high school and primary school ndash but its narrowness does not allow for a raised pavement.Residents attended a North Berwick Community Councilmeeting last week to share their ldquonear-miss experiences.Ian Watson, a long-serving community councillor, put forward traffic lights as a possible solution.He told the meeting: ldquoI propose that traffic lights like the ones [at the bridge] in Pencaitland are the best way forward.Mr Watson was referring to the lights that are in place at the narrow bridge on the A in Pencaitland.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, told the meeting: ldquoThere is money waiting to be spent from Cala [from a housing development in the town] and I think that you have just discussed what you need to do to spend it.Claire Mackenzie, interim chairwoman of the community council, said the group would write to East Lothian Council to find out how much has been ring-fenced.Mrs Mackenzie described the bridge, the only route over the townrsquos railway line, as a ldquodisaster.She said: ldquoI know people who are so worried about there being an accident there that they just avoid the bridge altogether.Members also discussed a proposal from NBCC member Gordon Moodie for a second bridge to be built across the railway line.On that suggestion, Mr Watson added: ldquoThat is something that we can dothere is [a lot of] money but it is an expensive solution.NBCC wants to engage with the community, including Law Primary School and North Berwick High School, about what they feel is the best solution.

title: smacking-plans-backed-by-less-than-a-third-of-people-poll-suggests
story: A Panelbase survey of more than , people for The Sunday Times Scotland found that % said they support the measure, which has the backing of the Scottish Government.More than halftold pollsters they believe smacking should still be allowed, while % said they did not know.Legislation aimed at banning smacking was published at Holyrood last month.Green MSP John Finnie introduced the Children Bill after gaining the backing of Scottish ministers and MSPs from across all the political parties.If passed, the legislation would remove the defence of ldquojustiable assault in Scots law, which allows parents to use physical punishment to admonish a child.Mr Finniersquos Memberrsquos Bill is also supported by a range of organisations including the Scottish Police Federation, Barnardorsquos Scotland, the Church and Society Council of the Church of Scotland and the NSPCC.But the move is opposed by campaign group Be Reasonable Scotland ndash backed by The Christian Institute and The Family Education Trust ndash which argues a ban will ldquocriminalise parents.A Be Reasonable spokesman said the Scottish Government is ldquoout of touch with the public on the issue.He said: ldquoThe question for MSPs is not whether you should smack your children. It is whether you want to criminalise hundreds of thousands of parents who do.ldquoThe clear evidence is that the vast majority of Scots do not back a ban. Those people need to communicate this to their MSPs before itrsquos too late.Responding to the poll, the Scottish Government pointed to findings from  which it said showed that % of people say children should have the same protection or greater protection than adults from assault.A spokeswoman said: ldquoThe Scottish Government supports positive parenting.ldquoThis proposed Bill will give children the same legal protections as adults ndash something backed by an overwhelming majority of public opinion ndash and end the defence of lsquojustiable assaultrsquo.Panelbase surveyed , voters, the newspaper said.

title: disappearance-of-saudi-journalist-being-treated-with-utmost-seriousness-hunt
story: Reports claim the Washington Post columnist was killed while visiting the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, with Turkish authorities reported to have obtained audio andvideorecordings of the alleged murder.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt and his French and German counterparts said they had ldquograve concerns about the situation and called for a credible investigation into what happened.ldquoDefending freedom of expression and a free press and ensuring the protection of journalists are key priorities for Germany, the United Kingdom and France, the three ministers said.ldquoIn this spirit, light must be shed on the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, whose family has lost contact with him since October .Mr Hunt, Francersquos Jean-Yves Le Drian and Germanyrsquos Heiko Maas said they were treating the incident with ldquothe utmost seriousness.ldquoThere needs to be a credible investigation to establish the truth about what happened, and ndashrelevant ndash to identy those bearing responsibility for the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, andensure that they are held to account, they said.ldquoWe encourage joint Saudi-Turkish efforts in that regard, and expect theSaudi Government to provide a complete and detailed response.ldquoWe have conveyed this message directly to the Saudi authorities.The disappearance of Mr Khashoggi has placed the relationship between the Gulf kingdom and the West under intense strain.US President Donald Trump has threatened ldquosevere punishmentauthorities determine Saudi Arabia was behind Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance.The Saudi government has dismissed the allegations against it as ldquobaseless.The intervention by Mr Hunt and his allies followed criticism from Labour about the Governmentrsquos response.Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberrysaid there had been ldquonothing but pusillanimous mutterings from Mr Hunt on the issue.ldquoHe is being outdone by Donald Trump, whoever would have thought that  she said on the BBCrsquos The Andrew Marr Show.ldquoTheyrsquore playing catch-up with Donald Trump when it comes to condemnation of this and actually taking action and being prepared to stand firm.Ms Thornberry said the alleged murder was ldquoyet more evidence of how the Saudi prince in particular appears to be out of control and ldquothis country has had enough.Commons Foreign Affairs Committee chairman Tom Tugendhat said on Saturday that the UK should work with its allies on its response, and that International Trade Secretary Liam Fox should boycott the Future Investment Initiative in Riyadh later this monthSaudi involvement in Mr Khashoggirsquos disappearance was proved.The Department for International Trade said: ldquoThe Secretary of Statersquos diary is yet to be finalised for the week of October , we will update on his activity in due course.A critic of Saudi Arabiarsquos de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Mr Khashoggi was living in self-imposed exile in the US and writing opinion pieces for the Washington Post before he vanished.He visited the consulate on October  to obtain a document confirming he had orced his ex-we, in order to allow him to remarry.Turkish officials have said he was killed on the premises and his body removed.

title: sky-sports-reporter-blasts-hoops-fans-accusing-her-of-gers-bias-and-reveals-what-side-she-really-backs
story: Trolls accused Hayley McQueen of backing Rangers after a group of Hoops fans were unhappy with Skys Coverage of a recent match.Why you think Irsquom a Rangers fan, god knows, itrsquos obviously what you want to believe. title: is-this-the-worlds-unhealthiest-pizza-glasgow-takeaway-launches-deep-fried-mars-bar-calzone
story: Described as a lsquoGlaswegian twistrsquo on the Italian food it is served with grated almonds on top of the pizza dough, caramel sauce and a scoop of chocolate ice cream.It is packed with Mars Bar chunks then cooked in batter and dubbed by locals as the Mars-gherita Pizza.With an estimated , calories packed into the snack, sold at Romans Pizzeria in Merchant City, Glaswegians have been flocking to try it.The takeaway is inspired by the notorious deep-fried Mars Bar treat invented in  at a Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire, chippy - Haven Chip Bar .Romanrsquos general manager, Fraser Walker, said the idea behind the deep fried Mars Bar calzone came from a simple conversation with the head chef.The -year-old, from Kelvindale, said: "Well the shop has been open here for about five and a half months and we wanted to bring out something dferent."This is because we are known for our Roman-style pizza, and after speaking to the chef about dferent ideas we came up with that."Weve seen restaurants adding Nutella in a calzone so we just thought the deep fried mars bar is a Scottish thing. So why not put it in a calzone "Its definitely not a dessert for someone who is on a diet."I would say people should share it because its very sweet unless you have a sweet tooth or are really hungry."Costing pound., the calzone has been a hit with punters, with one person even asking a relative to send a pizza to Germany.Head chef, Dawid Radzinski, said: "Ive been a chef for  years and what weve done is completely original."When I first made it, we all tried it together and we all loved it. The dessert has been here since Monday and people think its really tasty."I think this was a great idea"INGREDIENTS:" pizza dough   caloriesTwo deep fried mars bars  , caloriesCaramel sauce g   caloriesOne tablespoonof sugar   caloriesA handful of almonds   caloriesOne scoop of chocolate ice cream   caloriesTotal  , calories

title: independent-scotland-would-be-welcomed-back-into-eu-labour-grandee-says
story: David Martin ndash the second longest-serving MEP in Europe ndash said sympathy was growing in Brussels over Scotland being ldquoforced out of the EU against its will.He said negotiations would be ldquoquick given Scotland would meet nearly all of the conditions for membership, and argued a ldquobespoke deal would enable it to stay out of the eurozone.Scottish Labour dismissed his remarks as "hypothetical statements which do not reflect Scottish Labour policy in any way, shape, or form.Mr Martin said Scotlandrsquos future membership of the EU was not ldquohigh on peoplersquos agenda in Brussels, but added: ldquoIt is talked about, and there are people who would not previously have been sympathetic to the idea of an independent Scotland ndash colleagues of mine, Irsquom talking non-British colleagues ndash who now talk about it openly and say to me, lsquoAre you going to be an independent country, are you likely to join as a separate country rsquoldquoI think there is a dference between now and the time of the Scottish referendum where we were seen to be leaving a member state and we were pulling ourselves out of the EU in some peoples eyes.ldquoThis time around weare being forced out of the EU, which is how it is perceived here.ldquoThey know that Scotland voted to Remain and I think they would be very sympatheticScotland came back and said, lsquoScotland became independent and it wants to join the EUrsquo. It would be welcome.He said a bespoke deal on joining the euro would be offered ldquobecause other countries have it and it wouldnrsquot be a problem that you didnrsquot sign up to the euro.A major SNP report earlier this year suggested keeping the pound for at least ten years after independence, before moving towards a new currency.It insisted Scotland would not be obliged to join the euroit became a member of the EU, pointing to the example of other countries such as Sweden and Denmark.Mr Martin, a Labour MEP since , said plans to keep the pound ndash as outlined in the SNPs Growth Commission report ndash would probably be accepted by Brussels.He said Scotland would not have to queue behind others seeking to gain membership ndash such as Montenegro, Serbia and Albania ndash but would ldquohave to nevertheless go through the process of the negotiation and fulfill all the conditions.Mr Martin previously refused to rule out backing independence in order to secure links with Europe.A Scottish Labour spokesman insisted his remarks did not reflect party policy.He added: ldquoIf Brexit has made one thing clear, it is that there are severe challenges in leaving a political and economic union. All of the challenges we see with leaving the EU would be repeated on a much larger scale with leaving the UK.An SNP spokeswoman said: ldquoBrexit means there is now a much more positive view of an independent Scotland among our European friends and neighbours.ldquoAnd the Toriesrsquo shambolic handling of Brexit has killed off the credibility of any future lsquoProject Fearrsquo campaign against independence.ldquoScotland has been part of the EU for  years, meaning we already meet the rules, so we would be very well prepared to join as an independent nation."

title: pressure-mounts-on-theresa-may-as-brexit-summit-looms
story: As negotiations continue in Brussels ahead of a summit starting on Wednesday, the Prime Minister faces a political battle over a plan which could keep the UK in a customs union to avoid a hard border with Ireland.Former Brexit secretary David Davis said the plan was ldquocompletely unacceptable and urged Cabinet ministers to ldquoexert their collective authority.Meanwhile Democratic Unionist Party leader Arlene Foster is reported to have said that a no-deal Brexit was now the most likely outcome after talks with senior figures including Michel Barnier in Brussels.Her party is opposed to any customs arrangement which would result in Northern Ireland being ldquoannexed or impose extra checks on goods travelling to or from Great Britain.With continued speculation that Leave-supporting Cabinet ministers could resignMrs May presses ahead with the plan, David Davis said: ldquoThis is one of the most fundamental decisions that government has taken in modern times.Writing in the Sunday Times he said: ldquoIt is time for the Cabinet to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.The issue of the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland is one of the last remaining obstacles to achieving a orce deal with Brussels, with wrangling continuing over the nature of a ldquobackstop to keep the frontier opena wider UK-EU trade arrangement cannot resolve it.The European Unionrsquos version, which would see just Northern Ireland remain aligned with Brusselsrsquo rules, has been called unacceptable by Mrs May and is loathed by the DUP.The Sunday Times said at least nine ministers want Mrs May to change course when the Cabinet meets on Tuesday.Speculation about possible resignations has centred on Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey, but the newspaper also indicated that Scottish Secretary David Mundell and Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson could quit because special arrangements for Northern Ireland could fuel the case for Scottish independence.Mrs Mayrsquos own position also appeared in jeopardy, with as many as  letters demanding a vote of no confidence reportedly submitted to the Conservative  Committee ndash just four short of the number required to trigger a ballot.The Northern Irish situation is politically problematic for Mrs May because her minority administration depends on the votes of the  DUP MPs.A leaked email reported in the Observer indicated Mrs Foster was ready to block a Brexit deal.According to a private email exchange between senior UK officials, seen by the newspaper, Mrs Foster gave her views during a dinner with the leader of Conservative MEPs, Ashley Fox.The leaked email said Mrs Foster described the EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator Mr Barnier as ldquodficult and hostile and indicated ldquothe DUP were ready for a no-deal scenario, which she now believed was the likeliest one.Writing in the Belfaston Saturday, Mrs Foster said she appreciated the risks of a no-deal Brexit but ldquothe dangers of a bad deal are worse.She added: ldquoThe DUPrsquos actions this week are not as some have suggested about lsquoflexing musclersquo.ldquoThis is no game.ldquoAnyone engaging in this in a light-hearted way foolishly fails to grasp the gravity of the decisions we will make in the coming weeks.

title: princess-eugenie-and-jack-brooksbank-release-official-wedding-photographs
story: One intimate black and white image shows the couple having a kiss inside the Scottish State Coach as they ed to Windsor Castle after the carriage procession.The newlyweds are said to be title: co-operative-party-backs-peoples-vote-on-brexit-deal
story: The Co-operative Party, which has  MPs who are jointly members of Labour, also backed continued membership of the single market.At the partyrsquos conference in Bristol, delegates also rejected the prospect of a no-deal Brexit and said the Article  period should be extendedan agreement has not been reached by March .The explicit call for a second referendum goes further than Labourrsquos position, which is only to keep the option of a public vote on the tablea Brexit deal is rejected by Parliament and there is not a general election.The @CoopParty Conference confirms strong supp for a public Vote on whether to accept the Brexit deal  that that deal should include m ship of and access to the Single Mkt. title: iain-macwhirter-the-bottom-line-in-brussels-is-that-mays-hybrid-backstop-doesnt-work-for-scotland-or-the-uk
story: Its a posture that would appeal to Boris Johnson. He too wants to give the ECJ the bums rush. He regards the court as an instrument of ldquocolonial domination, imposing an alien legal code on Britain. The main reason he wants to ldquochuck Chequers is because Theresa Mays latest Brexit plan leaves the European Court of Justice as the ultimate authority on trade disputes. Actually, on this at least, the bouffant Brexiteer is correct.Its more complicated, of course, everything to do with Brexit is. The latest backstop proposal for resolving the Irish border problem seems to involve Britain remaining in the Customs Union for an indefinite period and for Northern Ireland to remain in regulatory alignment with the European Single Market. Brussels insiders, like the Labour MEP, David Martin, of the parliaments International Trade Committee, believe a deal along these lines has already been done behind the scenes. It remains only for the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, to announce it, in great fanfare, this week.Butmy soundings in Brussels are correct, there is almost zero chance of it being agreed ndash at least by the Brexiteers. This is because,Britain remains even partially in the single market and the Customs Union under the so called ldquohybrid backstop, that leaves the UK still subject to the European Court of Justice. And these people dont mess about.The top legal adviser to the European Court, Advocate-General Eleanor Sharpston is about as tough as they get - shes a karate black-belt for a start. She made it clear that theres no bucking the ECJ. ldquoThis court decides what the single market rules are, and that isnt going to change. Theresa May can try to claim that Britain is not under the ldquodirect jurisdiction of the ECJ ndash perhaps by having the UK Supreme Court act as intermediary ndash but the inescapable legal reality is that it is. The ultimate arbiter for disputes about the European Single Market and the Customs Union is the Luxembourg bench.Boris Johnson understands this. He says that, under this weekrsquos proposed deal: ldquoWe cannot escape the EU laws and ECJ until they allow us to ndash which they may never do. He goes on to say that this makes Britain a ldquocolony which is of course ridiculous. There is a world of dference between a court that deals with disputes over trade and related matters, and the supreme legal authority of a nation state.Whenever countries join a rules-based international trading system they agree to share sovereignty. The World Trade Organisation , the hard Brexiteers hard backstop, also has an arbitration procedure. The European Free Trade Association, has a court. Thai doesnt mean that members of EFTA or the WTO cease to be independent countries. Perhaps the greatest mistake made by Theresa May in these entire negotiations has been to go along with the fiction that Brexit means ldquotaking back our laws. We never lost them.Even the UK governments own White Paper on Brexit made this clear in February  when it said that the UK parliament ldquoremained sovereign throughout our membership of the EU. It went on to say that ldquoit didnt always feel like that, but the constitutional situation has never been in doubt. We never lost control of our laws, except in very narrowly defined areas. The demonising of the European Court of Justice has been a disastrous error of rhetoric, which has led many people to believe the canard that ndash as the Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt put it at the Tory Conference in Birminghamndash the EU is a ldquoprison like the old ldquoSoviet Union from which Britain is ldquoescaping.This equation of the EU with the USSR, which has become commonplace among Tory eurosceptics, has caused genuine outrage across the European Union ndash especially in central European countries which actually experienced soviet domination. Try suggesting to someone from a Baltic state, like Lithuania, that the EU is prison. Theyll tell you, forcefully, that it was the European Union that helped them escape from communist domination. First by giving them a model of freedom, prosperity and human rights, and second by allowing them to become members of a union founded on the autonomy of independent nations.There was a palpable change of mood in Brussels last week following the rhetoric of that Tory conference. Britains friends in the Brussels have mostly given up trying to defend UK ministers. Officials, politicians, and Brussels commissioners just want an end to this whole demeaning Brexit process ndash and they dont much care how. Theyve other, more important things on their minds, like populism, Italy, Putin, Trump.And I have to say, therersquos very little support in Brussels for Nicola Sturgeons call to delay the implementation of Article  next March. That would need the agreement of all  remaining states and officials now believe that is most unlikely. This is partly because EU governments just refuse to prolong the agony. This weeks deal looks final.And it poses very serious problems for Scotland. If Northern Ireland remains in the single market, this will be a huge attraction for firms wishing to gain the benefits of working within the EU without leaving the UK. It gives the North a massive competitive advantage over Scotland. Nicola Sturgeon is right to demand parity. But theres no way she is going to get it. Senior Brussels commissioners dismiss out of hand the idea of Scotland getting a similar deal. They wont even talk about it ndash Ive tried.There is some sympathy in the European Parliament for Scotlandrsquos plight: being forced out of the EU against its will. According to David Martin, theres now a real willingness to help Scotland rejoin the EU,it were to become independent. But that is very much for the future. The EU only deals with member states, in this case the UK, and right now they just want rid the lot of us.My problem is that I cant see how the UK parliament can endorse this weeks hybrid backstop. It may well be that a technical solution to the issue of Irish border checks is not far off. There are already health and environmental checks on agricultural goods and food coming from Northern Ireland to Britain. This could be the basis for a future ldquofrictionless border between Northern Ireland, which remains partially in the single market, and the UK which remains largely out of it.But the DUP are having none of it. Britain remaining for an indefinite period in the Customs Union is a non-starter for Tory Brexiteers. The SNP must oppose NI exceptionalism and Chequers doesnt meet Labourrsquos ldquosix tests. Britainrsquos been asking for the impossible. If you remain even partially in regulatory alignment you must accept ECJ rulings. As with Paolozzis statue, thats the bottom line.

title: watchdog-criticises-snp-government-over-proposed-freedom-of-information-reforms
story: Ministers agreed to make changes after the watchdog issued a critical report into the way the Government dealt with FOI in relation to groups including journalists.Daren Fitzhenry, the SIC, has now expressed concern about an apparent lack of ldquoclarity in the continuing role of special advisers and ministers in the process.Scotlandrsquos FOI law, which came into force in , gives citizens a right to information held by public bodies, unless it is covered by an exemption.However, journalists from across the media last year signed an open letter complaining about the way the SNP Government handled their requests.They complained of delaying tactics and requests being blocked or refused for tenuous reasons.The reporters also claimed that their questions were being routinely handled by special advisers, who are political appointees, and screened for potential political damage.Fitzhenry launched a review into the claims and he found that Government policy reinforced concerns of a two tier system for journalists, MSPs and political researchers.He concluded there had been ldquounjustiable, signicant delays and disregard for the statutory timescales and noted the Government took longer to respond to journalistsrsquo requests than others.Fitzhenryrsquos report also stated that the Government policies and procedures were not ldquoclear enough about the role of special advisers in responding to FOI requests.Oppositions politicians claimed that the role of special advisers amounted to interference in the FOI system.However, the Governmentrsquos ldquodraft action plan makes clear that special advisers ndash otherwise known as spads ndash will stay have a role at the end of the process.ldquoCases identied as sensitive or exceptionally complex will, after clearance, be referred to SPADs and ministers for comment, the draft states.In his response to Government, Fitzhenry said he was ldquocontent with the ldquomajority of the proposed actions, but noted: ldquoI note that, for example, cases identied as sensitive or exceptionally complex will be referred to special advisers and Ministers for comment after clearance. I am concerned that this will not provide the desired clarity or transparency.ldquoAs my report provided, the role of ministers and special advisers must be made clear to all in the process, including requesters.Neil Findlay, Scottish Labourrsquos parliamentary business manager, said:ldquoThe SNP governmentrsquos response to the damning report earlier this year into their misuse of Freedom of Information laws is nothing more than a sham.ldquoInstead of stopping politicians and taxpayer funded spin doctors interfering in journalists requests they have institutionalised it.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoAs is well known, the Scottish Government co-operated fully with the Scottish Information Commissionerrsquos recent comprehensive independent review of our Freedom of Information practice and performance.ldquoFoI legislation allows for special advisers and ministers to be involved in the process and that the Commissioner found no misuse of FoI law by the Scottish Government.ldquoIt is important to note that at no point in any of the seven key recommendations in the Commissionerrsquos report does he suggest that special advisers should not continue to provide advice to ministers and colleagues, as is their proper .

title: the-anatomy-of-a-horror-film-the-perfect-recipe-for-a-great-fright-flick
story: I WATCHED my first horror movie when I was four years old. I crept downstairs one night in the early s and opened the door to the living room without my mum and dad knowing. A film was on TV ndash this was during the glory days of the BBCrsquos late night weekend Horror Double Bill.It was The Masque of the Red Death ndash which I now declare to be the greatest horror film ever made. It was wild, terrying, demented. A man in a gorilla suit was burned alive by a dwarf, Death walked the Earth, nobles partied within the walls of a castle as the plague raged outside. It blew my tiny mind and scared me witless, but I kept silent, hidden behind the sofa, as I knew it was taboo andmy parents realised I was there, theyrsquod send me to bed.On screen was an actor I would come to love ndash Vincent Price as the evil Prince Prospero. My parents only discovered I was there when the National Anthem started playing, and they turned on the lights and found me, goggle-eyed like some creepy imp in flannel pyjamas.Irsquove spent the rest of my le watching horror films ndash so as the witching season approaches, and the latest Halloween movie gets ready to open in cinemas, I thought Irsquod give you a guide to the secrets of the genre ndash and tell you what really makes a fright flick tick.THE WOODSIt doesnrsquot have to be the woods ndash though it often is ndash but location is as important to a horror movie as it is to Kirsty Allsopp and Phil Spencer. Think of Jonathan Harkerrsquos journey to Transylvania ndash a scene which opens countless Dracula films. The mountains, the inn, the forest, the wolves, the fog, the night ... the castle. A Dracula movie would be as naked without its classic location as the count without his cape.A great location doesnrsquot have to be some gothic throwback either. Look at An America Werewolf in London ndash it fetishises both the English countryside and the grungy grimy London of the early s ndash or the spaceship in Alien, which becomes a white, pared-back, claustrophobic hunting ground.The ballsiest horrors find the most unlikely location and just go for it ndash all great horror films take enormous risks with everything from script to casting and lightning to sound ndash so how about: a creepy ballet school for girls, soaked in vivid technicolour, in Dario Argentorsquos Suspiria a ski lt in Frozeninside a grave in Buried a railway carriage in Train to Busana punk rock venue in The Green Room, or a locked house in Donrsquot Breathe.None of these films would workthe director had chosen another setting ndash the setting is as important as the characters, the killings, and the creeps that the films wring from you.THE JUMPSHave you ever caught the Luton Bus  Or rather the Lewton Bus  If yoursquove watched the s movie Cat People by Val Lewton then yoursquoll know what I mean.In one scene we see our heroine being hunted by a killer we expect to turn into a panther at any moment. The tension builds and just when wersquore sure itrsquos all going to end in blood and fur, a bus screeches by making viewers leap from their seats. Therersquos no murder, no mayhem ndash but it is famously the scariest part of the film. If you donrsquot jump at least once in a horror movie, whatrsquos the point, most fans would say  We come to be scared.Bad directors use music to make you jump ndash a screeching violin is not a scare ndash or cliche, like Jason Voorhees ndash the killer in the Friday the th franchise ndash leaping up from the dead just when we think wersquore safe. Great film-makers like Lewton use your mind to make you jump, nothing .What a good jump scare depends on is sudden unexpected movement ndash tapping into that fear we have of something unexplained glimpsed from the corner of your eye. Look at the "Sloth" scene in Seen: the camera lingers over a shrivelled body which police have found tied to a bed. Suddenly, the "corpse" moves, struggling in its bonds. The entire set-up is overturned ndash a body we thought was dead, isnrsquot.The switch itself implies something ghastly: whatever is on the bed has been suffering for months in agony. In one split-second, David Fincher physically and emotional terrorises us.Perhaps, the greatest jump scare is in the much underrated The Exorcist III where a satanic killer is on the loose. One two-minute scene features a static long shot of a hospital hall. A nurse is making her rounds at night ndash her red cardigan the only colour on screen.Nothing  happens ndash but we know something has to happen, this is a horror movie. Just as the audience is lulled into a sense of calm, a shroud-draped man with a giant pair of medical shears ndash the kind used for amputations ndash charges at the nurse from behind.I remember audibly screaming in the cinema in  at this scene ... I loved it.THE MONSTERThere are three main types of baddie in horror films: the Monster, the Psycho, and the Thing. Letrsquos start with the monster.First of all, the Monster isnrsquot human and thatrsquos whatrsquos frightening. Whether itrsquos the shark in Jaws, whatever the hell is in the woods in The Blair Witch Project, the house in The Haunting of Hill House, giant ants in the s creature feature Them!, the xenomorph in Alien, or the demons from The Mist ndash these monsters are relentless. They will not stop ndash and we cannot fathom what drives them, beyond a desire to kill, yet they also possess a preternatural human-like intelligence.Monsters create unanswered questions ndash and ignorance means fear: Why is this shark out for revenge  What is running wild in the woods  Why wonrsquot the house stop shaking  Why are those ants the size of a Ford Focus  Why is that alien hugging my face  What are demons doing in a suburban supermarket The Monster works on the fear of the unknown, or the ugly ndash fear of the non-human. The Monster plays on those deep-seated fears we experience as children ndash the creature under the bed at night, or something beneath your feet when yoursquore swimming.THE PSYCHOThe Psycho, however, works on the opposite emotion ndash the fear of fellow humans, that behind our smiles and civilised cappuccinos lie salivating lunatics eager to kill.What better place to start with the Psycho, then, than with Hitchcockrsquos Norman Bates. The original Psycho was based on a real murderer ndash a necrophile, mother-killing, grave-robbing Wisconsin weirdo called Ed Gein .The roots of the Psycho always lie in reality ndash thatrsquos the fear factor. Could we one day meet such killers in real le  Might we already know a Hannibal Lecter, the urbane cannibal psychiatrist with a nose for good perfume and an eye for cheap shoes a Patrick Bateman, the boardroom American Psycho a Jack Torrance from The Shining ndash the intellectual family man about to snap and kill.THE THINGWhen it comes to the Thing, itrsquos all about the Uncanny Valley ndash the psychological theory that when something resembles a human being closely, but just not quite enough, it elicits a horrible feeling of dread.Think of Nosferatursquos spindly long-fingered decaying fiend, the creature in the attic in Rec, Frankensteinrsquos creation bolted together from scraps of corpses, any zombie, the demonic Cenobites from Hellraiser, the baby in Eraserhead, possessed Regan in The Exorcist, even Hal from : A Space Odyssey.These creatures almost look like us, or in Halrsquos case sound like us, but we know they are not us ndash and so they scare the daylights out of us.THE SALLYIt was once standard operating procedure in horror films that there would always be a survivor ndash usually a woman, known in the industry by the slightly sexist term "The Last Girl".I prefer to call this survivor character "The Sally" in homage to the female lead in The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Sally Hardesty, played by s scream queen Marilyn Burns. Texas is loved and hated in equal measure. Horror fans hail it as the darkest and cleverest of the ultra-violent classic slasher films.PhDs have been written on Texas. Itrsquos even been interpreted as a comment on Watergate ndash the deranged hill billy cannibal serial killers do live in a big "white house" after all. People who donrsquot watch horror films, though, detest Texas as little more that snuff-inspired torture porn.Director Tobe Hooper put his Sally character through hell at the hands of Leatherface, grandpa and the rest of the slavering clan. When I first watched Texas during the s video nasty era, I felt physically broken afterwards ndash the violence, the terror, the bestial nature of what was happening on screen literally overwhelmed me.But Sally survived ndash and because Sally survived, good won the day. Horror films often rely on such simply fairy tale tricks ndash make me feel scared but then offer hope that what scared me will be defeated and the result is Pavlovian, punters come back for more.Sally led to Laurie Strode, the lead character in the original  Halloween. Now Laurie is dferent to Sally. Sally does a lot of running and screaming and crying ndash Laurie does a lot of running and hiding and trying to breath quietly in cupboards, but then something very important happens: Laurie turns on the killer, the villain Michael Myers.In fact, at one point, we think shersquos killed Myers, clad in his creepy William Shatner face mask . But, in a tradition that Halloween basically forged, the bogeyman lives to kill another day. Nevertheless, he was still vanquished, for the time being at least, by the female protagonist who remains standing.Sometimes, though, The Sally doesnrsquot survive ndash a development seen increasingly in films with a strong artistic bent. In the nihilistic masterpiece Funny Games, Michael Hanekersquos Pinteresque descent into hell, the end is one of deliberate despair ndash no-one will live, and the killers are coming for you next.THE SEXESUnsurprisingly, given that horror exploits our real fears, most villains are men. Horror movies draw very heavily on a primordial battle of the sexes theme: the brutal killer, often a mere personication of evil, versus the sparky, clever woman pushed to the limits of endurance.However, not all horror films conform to the genre. Some switch, and the female villain is far from unknown ndash but when you analyse why the woman is a killer, itrsquos for very dferent reasons to the men.Women donrsquot pick up chainsaws and go on mindless murder sprees ndash women killers tend to act out psychologically, and that can can often create the greatest of screen villains. For proof, enter Annie Wilkes from Misery, an obsessive fan with a fine line in moral rectitudeand a taste for torture.In recent decades, more women began to pop up who should have been put in a straitjacket from birth. Therersquos Lola Stone in The Loved Ones ndash a girl you donrsquot want to invite to a house party Tina, a murderous National Trust nerd, in Ben Wheatleyrsquos black comedy of modern manners Sightseers and Marie, the worst best friend a girl ever asked for in the French new wave horror Switchblade Romance.Carrie is probably the most nuanced female character in any horror film ndash she is both villain and victim. Abused by a religious maniac mother, bullied and sexually humiliated by her classmates, Sissy Spacek as Carrie becomes the revenge prototype of teen female anger.Increasingly, wersquore beginning to see men enter the role of the victim. Take the Belgian movie The Ordeal. Instead of a woman held captive by a male predator, it is a man who is imprisoned and tormented: a good way to bring home to the audience that often the gaze in horror films is on female suffering.THE MEANINGA great horror film has to say something ndash an awful horror film just drips blood all over the cinema seat and leaves you as unsatisfied as a ten pound box of popcorn. By "saying something", I donrsquot mean art house pretension ndash I mean that a horror movie must resonate with its times.Horror is the most mutable of genres, apart from comedy. People have fallen in love for the same reasons since time immemorial, people have sought revenge for the same reasons since time immemorial, but jokes change from one day to the next. Horror also changes, not because what scares us changesbut because for horror to work it must relate to you and the fears of the time in which you live.Yoursquoll not be scared by Little Red Riding Hood, but centuries ago it terried your ancestors. Whats needed to scare modern viewers is something that echoes in our real lives ndash think of all those s B movies rfing off the unseen menace of reds under the bed like Invasion of the Body Snatchers or Cronenbergrsquos body-horror movies, like The Fly, driven by the fear of technology there was even a spate of post-s hippie horrors in the wake of the Manson family killings like Last House on the Left.Probably the two best examples of horror movies tapping into modern fears come in the shape of Eden Lake, and Ils . Eden Lake uses fear of the dispossessed to get its hooks into viewers. It makes the viewer wonderthe poor, the uneducated, the forgotten will one day rise up and kill them.This is the horror of the housing estate. It is a brutal take on what happens when the suburban middle classes rub up against the "underclass".Ils ndash Them ndash is similar in tone but here it is children who are the terror. It prods at the hidden adult fear that children could quite easily killthey wished. Wersquove seen terrible crimes committed by bored, abused, forgotten children unfold in our papers and on the TV news ndash this film seems to say,you beat a dog long enough it will bite you back, no matter how weak it is.Irsquom not trying to convince anyone that horror is art ndash though as a fan of horror movies, I do think the genre is capable of high art when at its very best.In a strange way, what horror can do is make you feel alive because it makes you confront death. Thatrsquos probably what I realised in my four-year-old mind back in the early s when Vincent Price scared the pants off me in The Masque of the Red Death.As the old toast goes from The Bride of Frankenstein: "To a new world of Gods and Monsters!"

title: scotland-mops-up-after-storm-callum
story: Scotland is mopping up after Storm Callum, which brought heavy rain and flooding to swathes of the country.A Met Office yellow "be aware" alert for the south west of the country, the Lothians, Borders and Strathclyde areas was lted at midnight. Saturdayrsquos deluge came after a day of wet weather on Friday.Forecasters warned yesterday that homes and businesses could be flooded, causing damage to some buildings, while there is a chance of power cuts and loss of other services to some places.ldquoFast flowing or deep floodwater is possible, causing a danger to le, warned The Met Office.Wales and northwest England was also at risk of floods, with up to  mm of rain falling in some areas.ldquoFurther strong winds may bring down leaves and branches, increasing the likelihood of flooding due to blocked drains or culverts, the Met Office said.The Scottish Environment Protection Agencyissued two flood warnings, for the Upper Tay and Ballinluig to Logierait in Tayside. Lower level flood alerts were also in place for Dumfries and Galloway and the Borders.Sepas duty flooding manager David Faichney said yesterday the band of rain following Storm Callum would bring downpours of more than mm.He said: ldquoRivers are likely to risehellipI think there will be a lot of surface water. At this time of year, with leaves coming off the trees, drains tend to get blocked up... Flooding of roads, that will happen locally."Traffic Scotland urged motorists to drive with caution yesterday due to surface water on the roads. Flooding was reporting on section of the M.One motorist told the Herald on Sunday he saw a car lose control on the M near Glasgow, and hit the central reservation.ldquoI was travelling south from Forfar, said Alan Morrison. ldquoThe A was treacherous, with visibility poor and many drivers did not have their lights on. I saw a white BMW hit the central reservation on the M, about a mile from the junction with the M. There was a lot of standing water on the roads, with pools of water gathering in some places.On the transport network, some rail services were hit by delays, with the weather affecting the route between Preston and Scotland.Strong winds also saw speed restrictions imposed on many routes - with reduced Virgin services between London Euston, Birmingham New Street, and Edinburgh and Glasgow, Network Rail said.One of the worst affected areas in the UK was the village of Aberdulais in Neath Port Talbot where residents were ordered to evacuate their homes due to rising river levels amid reports of the worst floods there for  years.Meanwhile in the town of Crickhowell in the Brecon Beacons national park, where the River Usk burst its banks, some properties were also flooded, with up to ft of water.High winds brought by Storm Callum delayed the start of fracking at a site in Lancashire.Work was expected to get under way at Preston New Road, Little Plumpton, near Blackpool on Saturday after an environmental campaigner failed in a High Court bid to block operations.But energy firm Cuadrilla said fracking had been postponed until Monday as the region felt the effects of Storm Callum.Meanwhile, fresh landslips on Friday caused by Storm Callum as it swept the west of Scotland will keep the Rest and be Thankful closed over the weekend.Heavy rain and strong winds brought  tonnes of debris from the hillside on to the A in Argyll and Bute on Friday as operators tried to clear landslips from earlier in the week.The closure has caused a ersion for motorists. Bear Scotland said work is continuing to repair the debris fencing, clear the carriageway and reinstate drainage.North west manager Eddie Ross said: ldquoStorm Callum is continuing to bring more heavy rain to the area, limiting visibility and making conditions dficult for the teams to progress repairs and the clear-up of yesterdays additional landslides.ldquoDespite this, teams are working exceptionally hard to do all they can to make the area safe, however until then the road and the Old Military Road local ersion has to remain closed for safety reasons.ldquoWere aware of the impact this is having on the busy weekend and holiday traffic and were doing all we can to help ensure the ersion route via the A at Dalmally keeps moving by having further safety patrols on the route to help any motorists as required.

title: future-shock-we-owe-david-icke-and-elon-musk-an-apology-if-quantum-experiment-proves-we-are-living-in-the-matrix
story: ldquoThe universe is an illusion, the goalkeeper-turned-Messiah told an unconvinced Terry Wogan during a now legendary TV interview in . Icke ndash who preferred to be called ldquoSon of the Godhead at the time ndash had failed to ingratiate himself to the bemused host, perhaps regretfully kicking off the chat by informing Wogan that the moon was a hollow alien spaceship.Personal eccentricities aside,it turns out Icke was correct about whatrsquos now dubbed the ldquoSimulation Argument, we all owe him an apology. The turquoise shellsuit and mullet remain utterly unforgivable, of course.Although this increasingly popular theory was first mooted by Greek philosopher Plato in BC then sweetened for popular consumption by The Matrix, itrsquos Oxford academic Nick Bostromrsquos recent paper supporting the concept that has lent it some heavyweight credibility.Respected US astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson gives it ldquobetter than - odds that the simulation hypothesis is correct. ldquoI wish I could summon a strong argument against it, but I can find none, is his unsettling conclusion. Impish billionaire futurist Elon Musk has also mused ndash to a chorus of groans from Tesla shareholders ndash that wersquore ldquomost likely in a simulation. It must be noted, however, that Musk was recently filmed smoking a rather large cannabis joint.If the Simulation Argument is indeed accurate, it means everything we understand as empirical, objective reality ndash the entire universe ndash may actually have only sprung into existence a millisecond ago. Like someone firing up their Xbox for a shot of Assassinrsquos Creed. Our memories saved data, surroundings a hologram and bodies simply avatars, programmed to perceive a notion of forward-movement we call ldquotime. This serves to anchor our ldquothoughts and allows us a concept of ldquofuture for an illusionary sense of ldquoself.But breathe, itrsquos not all bad news ndash the theory allows for one possibility that accepts yoursquore actually real. In fact, it suggests you are actually all that exists within this particular articial reality and that everything in the universe is simply the creation of your mind.This rather egotistical belief system is known as solipsism and sceptics who are  percent convinced of their own existence should note there are no definitive philosophical rebuttals to the theory. Itrsquos certainly a tragedy I canrsquot convince you of my own existence, even when my picture appears right next to these words. If you are indeed the one who is dreaming all this up, please note Irsquod appreciate a less ridiculous hairdo.Soit turns out the entire universe is just an infinitely isible virtual reality where molecules are pixels, itrsquos likely our lives are simply some computer game played by alien children. And I suspect those who controlled the avatars of Leonardo da Vinci, Shakespeare and Prince used cheat codes.Compute the mind of GodIF any of these unsettling musings truly reflect reality, then this simulationrsquos coding for irony is certainly in need of a debug this week.Researchers from the University of Basque in Spain are currently embarking upon a new venture to reveal the true nature of the universe ndash using, yes, a computer. They do say it takes a thief to catch a thief.Itrsquos actually doubly ironic that it is shiny new ldquoquantum computers that are being used to ldquorecreate the origin of Darwinian evolution.This is because events in quantum physics have a truly inexplicable and weird way of being influenced by observation ndash like a tree in the woods only falling when someone can see it. Some scientists believe such oddness at the molecular level of reality may be an actual quirkinside our simulation.These Spanish researchers, however, are clearly aware of the potential irony of asking a computer to essentially explain and understand itself. ldquoWe leave open the question whether the origin of le is genuinely quantum mechanical, confirmed one of the scientists involved, rather cryptically.Perhaps itrsquos no coincidence New Yorker magazine recently reported two unnamed tech billionaires have employed a number of scientists to work out how to break them out of the simulation using quantum computers.QUANTUM OF SOLACESo whatrsquos so special about these quantum computers compared to that shiny new Macbook you only use for surfing the net and assimilating into societys higher social tiers  Well, the truth is even those who construct quantum computers dont really understand the dference. But they believe the chasm is seismic.Todayrsquos mass market machines compute using an internal binary language of s and s, while quantum machines also have a third potential state that lies, well hellip somewhere in between. Because of this, their computational units ndash known as quibits ndash have the special ability to become "entangled" with other quibits. After entering such a relationship, quibits will then instantly reflect any changes in its lsquotwinrsquo.Why does this weird lsquomirroring matter  Well, many particle physicists believe itrsquos an action that actually takes place outside of what we perceive as spacetime. This is because distance seems to be no barrier to quibitsrsquo instant communication. And now, were slowly learning how to harness this ability in order to create machines of almost infinite computing power. Simply, your Macs s and s are very slow and the timeless dimension in-between is not. Forget that thing Richard Pryor created in Superman , wersquore talking machines as powerful as the Transformersrsquo home planet of Cybertron.LOOKING FOR LUCAIT may be the case that quantum machines donrsquot discover a simulation at the root of reality, but actually confirm that Darwinian evolution all boils down to the mysterious ancient leform known as LUCA .What makes this great granny of all things especially fascinating is that it had the chance of eternal le ndash but decided to die so we could live. Just like Jesus four billion years later.Most evolutionary biologists are convinced that everything that has ever existed originates from LUCA, and a genetic portrait was recently created by evolutionary biologists at the Heinrich Heine University in Duumlsseldorf. Apparently this oddity existed in deep sea vents on the magma-drenched, celestial baby Earth and was unlike anything  that has ever existed ndash a spindling conglomeration of tiny cells that spent hundreds of millions of years simply chilling in the sea doing nothing. Blind, deaf yet perhaps not so dumb.Itrsquos notable that gender or death did not exist on Earth until LUCA unzipped itself to kick off evolution, shuffling around its genetics using some mysterious early form of osmosis.Why this organism died to unleash its essential ingredients and create all le on this planet remains a deep, abiding mystery. Or perhaps LUCA was simply an alien virus in our simulation, programmed to self-destruct and seed this virtual Earth with avatars. If so, the creators of this particular illusion are playing a very long game indeed.AND FINALLY hellipEXPANDING further upon Oxford philosopher Nick Bostromrsquos recent Simulation Theory paper, whatrsquos particularly striking is its casual assumption of many long-lived alien civilisations existing out there.If these beings run computer simulations ndash and they will, says Bostrom ndash then articial realities must be abundant throughout the universe. The problem is, these alien programmers would ndash like us ndash have no idea whether theyrsquore part of a simulation themselves. Every universe may simply be a Russian doll trapped within the darkness of another ndash an artical multiverse.Yet,we are indeed living in the root level of reality, perhaps our universal common ancestor LUCA was still a computer virus of sorts ndash one that sacriced its original form to set evolution in motion, hoping to gain a multi-dimentional perspective of reality through the eyes of everything that has ever lived and died on Earth.From the birds in the sky to fungus in the fields, LUCA is likely hiding in plain sight, with infinite perceptions of reality at its disposal to understand and conquer its planet completely.And when its greatest achievement ndash humans ndash finally blast off to the stars, the entire universe awaits.

title: harry-and-meghan-to-embark-on-first-royal-tour-as-couple
story: The royal couple will visit Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand between October  and .Starting on Tuesday, Harry and Meghan will take part in  engagements over their -day trip to the Pacic region.The tour coincides with the Invictus Games in Sydney, which run from October -.The sporting event ndash founded by Prince Harry in  ndash gives sick and injured service personnel and veterans the opportunity to compete in sports such as wheelchair basketball and sitting volleyball.After landing in Sydney, the duke and duchess will travel to Dubbo and Melbourne, before spending three days in Sydney from October - to mark the launch of the games. They willfor the closing ceremony.However,sport is not the sole focus of the trip. While in Australia, Harry and Meghan will also visit organisations including schools and a rural Flying Doctor service, greet members of the public at the Sydney Opera House, and meet young leaders and community members at Government House.After Australia, the couple will fly to Fiji, where they will be greeted with an arrival ceremony similar to one attended by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh in .In Fiji, Prince Harry will pay tribute to Fijian war veterans and the couple will attend a state dinner, before flying to Tonga.The tour will conclude with a four-day trip to New Zealand, where they will be greeted by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern.The duke and duchess will learn about environmental challenges while in Wellington, visit a charity which supports children with parents in prison, andmeet members of the public in Auckland and Rotura.Harry and Meghan willto London from Auckland on November .Kensington Palace said in a statement: ldquoThere is a long history of friendship between the Royal Family and Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand, and their links with the UK are extensive.ldquoThe duke and duchess are very much looking forward to experiencing the unique cultures and customs of those four Commonwealth countries and have asked that this tour allow them opportunities to meet as many Australians, Fijians, Tongans, and New Zealanders as possible.

title: hopes-of-new-blackadder-series-dashed
story: The show starring Rowan Atkinson as the anti-hero Edmund Blackadder and Sir Tony Robinson as his hapless servant Baldrick was cult viewing in the s.Also featuring were Hugh Laurie, Tim
